Post title: How to find more bugs while testing
Post description: Following an embarassing bug that has been around since Moodle 2.1, and which no amout of testing has found until some poor user hit it, I wanted to pass on the following tip. When testing, and when you are inputting some text (e.g. a forum post, or answering an essay or shortanswer question, try to include all the tricky things that might cause Moodle to break, for example: < > & < > & ' "¬†\ \' \" \\ Êó•Êú¨Ë™û % %%¬†$@NULL@$ @@TEST@@ Some things that are there: Characters that have special meaning in HTML. The escaped equivalents of those. Single and double quote characters, and backslashes. Back-slash escaped versionso of those. Unicode characters outside the usual ASCII range. (That is Japan in Japanese.) Various other characters that occasionally get used with special meantings. Hopefully automated testing will start to do this too. See MDL-37858 .
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thanks Tim, big + 1, I've commented in MDL-37858
Comment 2: Thank you
Comment 3: Thanks Tim. That's really helpful.

Post title: Moodle 2.5 Text drag and drop not working in IE10.
Post description: Just been testing 2.5 on a clone of our site and loving the new features. I have enable the experemantal draging of text to test but it seems to work on firefox but not in IE10. All the other draging of pictures and content is working fine, but just cannot get dragging of txt to work. It is probable an issue with IE10 but would thought i would ask if anyone is having the same issues. Many Thanks David
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I don't have a copy of IE10 to test this with, but could you visit this page: http://jsfiddle.net/davosmith/7ZVag/2/ Once you are there, can you try dragging and dropping some text onto the 'drop content here' box and then post back the results (displayed below the box) into a reply here on this forum? With that info, I can see if it would be possible for IE10 to support drag & drop of text. Note it would be helpful to know what 'types' are displayed during the drag AND at the point where you do the drop (in case they are different) and if the content looks as you would expect. It would also be helpful if you could try dragging from a range of sources (e.g. Firefox => IE10, Word => IE10, Chrome => IE10, Notepad => IE10).
Comment 2: I have tried that from you site but the text from word to ie10, when you drag it to the drop content box the cursor turns into a shortcut cursor which tells me ie10 is not supporting the function for draging text. I have tried that site for firefox and chrome and they work fine.
Comment 3: OK that sounds like a straightforward IE10 does not support dragging of text, only dragging of files (I've not been able to test this myself). The jsfiddle is a vastly simplified version of the drag & drop code from Moodle, created to make it easier to solve incorrectly reported drag types in different browsers. So if it doesn't work on that site, it won't work in Moodle (nor is it possible to make it work in Moodle). Out of curiosity, does dragging links work (e.g. from the chrome address bar, or from a link on a page?)
Comment 4: drag and drop links work from chrome and firefox... but you guessed it not from IE10. i will have a play to see if its just a setting im missing or if it just is not supported at all in ie10 cheers for the help
Comment 5: Hi Davo, for the record, here are the exact feedbacks returned by your fiddle: TXT file: Types contained in the drag / drop: Files Content: <filename> PNG file: Types contained in the drag / drop: Files Content: <filename> Text from FF: Types contained in the drag / drop: Text Content: <empty> Text from Word: Types contained in the drag / drop: Text Content: <empty> Link from FF address bar: Types contained in the drag / drop: Text Content: <empty> Link from IE address bar: Types contained in the drag / drop: Text Url Content: <empty> Link (anchor) from HTML text: Types contained in the drag / drop: Text Url Content: <empty> HTH , Matteo
Comment 6: Thanks Matteo. I think that the answer is that IE10 just does not support drag & drop of text/links, so there isn't anything much that can be done about it (at least it supports drag/drop of files!).

Post title: Please fail QA tests when you find setType() warnings
Post description: Hi Testers, You may have noticed that there during testing of Moodle 2.5 release there are little warnings popping out of the woodwork whilst testing like: Did you remember to call setType() for 'id'? Defaulting to PARAM_RAW cleaning. This is a new developer warning, to help us improve the security/robustness of our forms in Moodle, introduced by MDL-34311 . We've noticed that a few of your have been encountering these messages and passing your tests because it does not affect the functionality of Moodle. I'd like to ask if you do encounter these warnings (or any other warning whilst running QA tests), please fail the test. We are aiming to eliminate any of these developer warnings before release, and having the failed QA tests is a good way to ensure we do not miss any of them. Thanks a lot for all your hard work testing Moodle 2.5! Dan

Post title: Categories are too easy to move
Post description: Hi guys Not sure about the location of this post but I'd like to inform the developers of an issue I came across. We have just finished implementing Moodle at 7 academies for a large government organisation. When I trained the administrators one of the things I showed them how to do was to add, remove and move categories. We soon found out that the current way of moving categories is potentially risky since there is no confirmation step. In the training session the people whom I trained followed along by doing as I did and when I demonstrated how categories are moved into other categories we ended up moving things into places that were no longer where they were initially. This was a very complicated scenario that eventually meant that I had to restore the original database since the system could no longer create new categories or courses. Unfortunately I no longer have the full detail of the errors etc but I do think that the process for moving a category requires some attention.

Forum Post: 
Post title: What QA tests do you run on your own test server?
Post description: What QA testing do you run on your own test server before going to another version of Moodle? ¬†I am a new Moodle administrator, and there is no process in place. ¬†I am planning to go from 2.3.2 to 2.3.3 this week. ¬†What type of testing do I need to do for that? ¬†Would it be different if I were going from 2.3.2 to 2.4? ¬†Do I double check the grades, look at quizzes, etc.? Or do you just assume it all will work fine? ¬†Does anyone have a process they go through before updating Moodle that they would be willing to share? Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can do minor upgrades like 2.3.2 to 2.3.3 with quite a lot of confidence, however, you are right to want to have a QA process in place. The basic approach is to apply the upgrade to a copy of your real site, and then test that the upgraded copy is working OK by clicking through some pages, and verifying that the functionality that you really care about sitll works. You need to think about who is going to actually do that, how much time then will have available, and whether they are the sort of person who needs a very rigid set of testing instructions, or whether they would be better of with something more open-ended. In either case, it is a good idea to try to build up a list of what the Moodle features you really rely on are, and focus your testing in those areas. For example, if you know that quiz X on course Y contains all the different question types that anyone uses on your Moodle site, then that would be a good quiz to test as part of the upgrade, because if that works, probably all the other quizzes work too. A major upgrade like 2.3.x -> 2.4.y is a much bigger deal. There may be significant new funcitonality, so as well as just testing that the site works after the upgrade, you may also need to announce the changes to your users. In any case, you should read the relevant release notes: http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Releases , to get a feel for what has changed in each release.
Comment 2: Thank you Tim!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Delay prevent some message popups
Post description: When testing you might find funktions that works as expected and therefore can be passed, though you find them strange or inappropiate. I have passed a test like that. When someone sends you a message you expect to get a popup if popups are activated in your settings and the sender also expect that you get a notification for the messages. But if you get 2 messages shortly after each other you will only receive a notification for the first message, which means that you might miss the second or won't see it until it is too late. As the system works now this is not a bug but a feature, there is a hard coded delay between popups to stop users who get a lot of messages being bombarded with popups. As I see it a delay can not stop spam if people know about the delay, but you can prevent the spam by blocking the spammers. The delay can only be irritating for people who do not know about it.. E.g. I send a message to you to tell you that the meeting will start a half hour later than planned. While you read my message I write a new because I forgot to say that you should not pick me up on the way. You do not read message number 2 because it came after you read the first but before the delay of sending out messages. So wouldn't it be better not to have the delay?

Post description: Hi, the Moodle 2.3 QA tests are now available in Moodle Tracker. We expect the 2.3 file usability stuff to land shortly. Don't forget that the files usability/file picker feature is now up and running on the Moodle QA test site and the tests, starting from number MDLQA-2313 are ready to run.

Comment 7: Hi, the word clone is added automatically when you clone - duplicate - and issue in Jira - Moodle Tracker. Because Tracker is not a test management tool it does not support test runs. Cloning the tests from a master copy is a workaround to allow us to create test runs for Moodle releases. I am currently evaluating test management tools that plug into Jira to improve this process.

Post title: Upgrade from 1.9 to 2.0 error writing to database
Post description: I was trying to upgrade a moodle site from 1.9 to 2.0 with some real data, it failed half way through mod_folder upgrades and I got the following errors: Debug info: Duplicate entry '2029' for key 'mdl_resoold_old_uix' INSERT INTO mdl_resource_old (oldid, course, name, type, reference, intro, introformat, alltext, popup, options, timemodified, cmid) SELECT r.id, r.course, r.name , r.type, r.reference, r.summary, 0, r.alltext, r.popup, r.options, r.timemodified, cm.id FROM mdl_resource r LEFT JOIN mdl_course_modules cm ON (r.id = cm.instance AND cm.module = ?) [array ( 0 => '13', )] Stack trace: line 394 of /lib/dml/moodle_database.php: dml_write_exception thrown line 682 of /lib/dml/my sql i_native_moodle_database.php: call to moodle_database->query_end() line 252 of /mod/resource/db/upgradelib.php: call to mysqli_native_moodle_database->execute() line 46 of /mod/folder/db/upgradelib.php: call to resource_20_prepare_migration() line 39 of /mod/folder/db/install.php: call to folder_20_migrate() line 468 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to xmldb_folder_install() line 265 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to upgrade_plugins_modules() line 1352 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to upgrade_plugins() line 290 of /admin/index.php: call to upgrade_noncore() any ideas? Thanks in advance, Lei
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lei, "line 290 of /admin/index.php: call to upgrade_noncore()" I suppose this means you have non-core plugins in your moodle 1.9 site? Try to remove them before doing the upgrade. Joseph
Comment 2: You are wrong here Joseph. upgrade_core() just does the core tables in lib/db/install. xml and upgrade.php. upgrade_noncore() does all the other datbase talbes which all belong to different plugins. Some of those plugins are part of the standard Moodle release. (I know people often use core to mean core + plugins in the standard release, but really that is sloppy usage.)
Comment 3: @Joseph, thanks for your advice. I'll try an upgrade without non-standard plugins. @Tim, thanks. One more question, is there anyway to tell which plugin breaks the upgrade process? From my debug info, entry '2029' is a youtube link, can I assume it's a plugin that use this resource break my upgrade?
Comment 4: The problem is occurring in the upgrade from the old 'resource' module to the new 'folder module'.¬†In Moodle 1.9 all the different types of resource were different sub-types of the 'resource' module. In Moodle 2.0 they have been made into completely separate modules, which solves a number of problems. So, the problem is in the upgrade from the old mod/resource/subtype/directory to the new mod/folder. To find the problem row in your old Moodle 1.9 database , you need to look at the mdl_resource row with id = 2029. Alternatively, you could try going to the URL .../mod/resource/view.php?r=2029 to see it in your browser.
Comment 5: Hi Tim, Once we go to that page through the url, then what? what do we do to fix it? sorry, I don't understand. Thanks
Comment 6: I experienced this error today. ¬†It seems to be caused by having more than one record in the¬†mdl_course_modules table referencing the same resource. The error message will tell you the id of the resource that is referenced more than once. ¬†Use the following SQL to locate it in your course: SELECT r.id, r.course, r.name, r.type, r.reference, cm.id as cmid FROM mdl_resource r LEFT JOIN mdl_course_modules cm ON (r.id = cm.instance) WHERE r.id = <resource_id>; Substitute the "duplicate entry" id number for <resource_id> above. ¬†In the OP 's case, this is '2029'. Run the SQL in your database client. ¬†You should get a result set like the following: +-------+--------+------------------------+------+------------------------+-------+ | id ¬† ¬†| course | name ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† | type | reference ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†| cmid ¬†| +-------+--------+------------------------+------+------------------------+-------+ | 39090 | ¬† ¬†835 | Exercise Suggestions 6 | file | estex06suggestions.htm | 50100 | | 39090 | ¬† ¬†835 | Exercise Suggestions 6 | file | estex06suggestions.htm | 50122 | +-------+--------+------------------------+------+------------------------+-------+ 2 rows in set (0.00 sec) Inspect the list of resources in that course by crafting a URL from the "course" field, e.g. http://yourmoodle.ac.uk/mod/resource/index.php?id=835 Search in the page for the text in the "name" column, in my case "Exercise Suggestions 6". ¬†The URL of the resource's link will tell you which cmid is in use, e.g. https://yourmoodle.ac.uk/mod/resource/view.php?id=50122 As long as there is only one link to the resource in the resource/index.php page, the other coursemodule record is safe to delete. So in my case, the following SQL deleted the record: delete from mdl_course_modules where id = 50100; Query OK (1 row affected ); Proceed with the upgrade as before. ¬†It will pick up where you left off.

Forum Post: 
Post title: QA for official maintenance releases vs weekly releases
Post description: Currently, we do not apply maintenance releases (e.g., 2.0.5) during a semester. ¬†We are considering changing that policy. ¬†If we do, is there any QA reason for preferring an official maintenance release (e.g., 2.0.5) over a weekly release (e.g., 2.0.5+)? ¬†For example, does the official maintenance release get more regression testing than a weekly release? Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Normally, there is wait of a few days between a weekly release like the final 2.1.1+, and then re-badging it and releasing it as Moodle 2.1.2. Therefore, if something critical is broken in a weekly release, it will probably be fixed before the real release. Also, when the integrators know a point release like 2.1.2 is coming up, they are probably a bit more risk-averse when reviewing changes. So, point releases like 2.1.2 probably are a little bit more stable, but it is marginal. The new development processes ( http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Process ) seem to be working well, so we get very few regressions in weekly releases. That is, all the official testing happens before the weekly release. All you get before the point release is a few days of community testing (that is, people reporting bugs when they find them). An equally good approach would be to take any weekly build at a time that suits you; wait for a week while watching to see if any serious new bugs are reported; and if not, use that weekly. I suppose the other thing you get from official releases is some release notes.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Automated Testing
Post description: Hi, Is anyone in the community performing automated testing? Ages ago we did look at Selenium, but found it a bit too bleeding edge, I just wonder if anyone has got further than we did. Thanks. Rod
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: We run a 400 line script in perl using WWW::Mechanize because we have fairly compex CAS chain that we need to analyze and monitor. We have another script using MozRepl with a virtual xwindows buffer (headless firefox ). We use WWW::Mechanize::Firefox with that though one could use Selenium instead. The Test::More/Mechanize framework in perl driving MozRepl is simpler than Selenium. Everytime we fix something we add a test in this headless firefox setup.. We also run monitors against rss feeds (our authentication is too complex for simple up/down monitoring) - we use Alertra and Simon for that. So we use 3 different systems for 1) performance testing, 2) regression testing, 3) up/down monitoring.
Comment 2: I've recently had good experience working with Selenium to create automated acceptance tests for a project quite similar to Moodle. I'd say Selenium is the right tool for this job and is quite mature as well. However, the tool is not the important thing, it's if the application is designed to support automated testing in the first place. I don't have any experience with Moodle just yet, so I can't say if this will be easy. Automated testing of Moodle is definitely something I will look into in the near future. If you (or someone else) is interested, I'd love to collaborate on this.

Post title: Automated testing
Post description: Hi guys. I'm new to Moodle. I work at the open university and would like to add automated tests to our¬†Moodle system using TestComplete. Has anyone here have some experience with ruuing Automated tests on Moodle? any tips or/and recommendations are welcomed. Thanks and good luck everyone. Carmit.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I guess (from your profile) that is The Open Unviersity of Israel, not the Open Unviersity, UK. Anyway. To answer your question. We have used jMeter, but that is mainly for load testing, not functional testing. About 5 years ago I tried using Selenium to test Moodle, but it is quite hard to write the scripts in a robust way that does not just break whenever Moodle changes. Still, Selenium has got better over the last few years. I don't know anything about TestComplete. But basically, any tool that can be used to test web applications in general should be usable to test Moodle, and it would be good if more people did more automated tests.
Comment 2: To add some more - at the OU (in the UK), we used jMeter for load testing as Tim has said. ¬†A little more detail here... http://www.open.ac.uk/blogs/XHProf/?page_id=64 We're also in the process of establishing functional testing using¬†HP QuickTest Professional - but that's at a fairly early stage.

The site is running painfully slow and I have had several failures (404 codes and allsorts). I have currently got the decaf theme running. Can anyone tell me what these errors relate to and if I need to do something to fix them? Or more correctly, what I need to do? I was going to copy the messages into this post but they're a tad long.. Thank you. Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: For convenience here is a typical error from the attached file. [06-Dec-2010 05:06:30] PHP Notice: ¬†enableavailability option was changed; rebuilding cache for course 5
  • line 3112 of /lib/moodlelib.php: call to debugging()
  • line 3115 of /lib/moodlelib.php: call to get_fast_modinfo()
  • line 3115 of /lib/moodlelib.php: call to get_fast_modinfo()
  • line 3115 of /lib/moodlelib.php: call to get_f in /home/bca19560/public_html/insegnanti-inglese.com/moodle/lib/weblib.php on line 2855 Comment 2: I do not think that is the problem, because if [06-Dec-2010 05:06:01] PHP Fatal error: ¬†Out of memory (allocated 60030976) (tried to allocate 39326 bytes) in /home/bca19560/public_html/insegnanti-inglese.com/moodle/lib/weblib.php on line 2855 there is no way Moodle could work reliably, it needs a lot more memory, sorry. Comment 3: Well, if I understand your comment, just how much memory does moodle 2 need to run? I'm using a shared server with 19 other sites and have never come across this problem before. Comment 4: It is not easy to say exactly how much: 64bit systems need a lot more memory PHP accelerators lower the memory usage more students, courses or content means more memory required In general for small sites I would recommend 96MB minimum limit, large sites should not have any hardcoded limits because it may require 512MB or more in some areas if you have a lot of users and data. Hopefully Moodle 2.0.1 will get some memory and performance improvements, but I doubt that schools could rely on Moodle with less than 64MB of memory. Petr ≈†koda Comment 5: I spoke to hostgator and asked how much memory is available. Their docs refer to 25% of the cpu. Their help woman said there is a 64Mb php memory limit. I didn't know there was such a thing as php memory.I assume that's like ram on a pc? Also they say that "php.apc is not compatible on shared hosting." I guess this all means that moodle 2.0 can't be used on a shared server with hostgator. Or any other shared server perhaps? Brian Comment 6: Hi Brian, Have you tried to adjust the, "Extra PHP memory limit" setting in your moodle installation which is there inside, "Server > Performance"? Does not your host let you customise php.ini file? Manish. Comment 7: Hi Manish, Yes I can customise php.ini but I can't increase the php memory limit. This much I know. As for "Extra php memory limit" adjust it in what direction? It is currently set at 128Mb which must have been a default setting as I haven't touched it, but it also says the default is 512Mb so obviously I can alter this...however if my php memory limit is 64Mb with hostgator will this make any difference anyway? Or is this something which works independently of the host? Brian Comment 8: Hi, If I were in your place I would try the following in sequence (it is possible that you have tried point no. 1 already, but still.....): 1. Change the appropriate line in php.ini to make it look as: memory_limit = 128M If it does not work, then make it memory_limit = 256M If that too does not work, believe the support and request them to make the change. If they do not agree, then 2. Change the theme from Decaf to something else which is less resource intensive if I do not want to change the host. 3. Change to a premium shared host or a VPS host. 4. After reading previous posts again, perhaps the point about extra php memory limit may not be applicable in your case as it most likely is limited to certain scripts and you seem to be having general issues. Manish. Comment 9: Manish, Thanks.. I've been busy this afternoon. I deleted the previous moodle2, along with the database and everything else that I could find. I created a new db and then did a fresh install. I hope that the problems I had were not related to the specific moodle release because I had to use the same one again. Now I can see what breaks before I add themes and courses. The first thing I did was do the functional db check, which gave me errors before. Lo and behold it flagged 3 fails and an exception immediately. I asked about these errors a day or so ago without joy, so I'll try again.I'm wondering if database errors are causing some of the problems I'm having. As for the php issue, I got the hosts to change me to php 5.3 so we'll see if that makes stuff faster. I'll let you know if I need to alter the settings and what happens.. Thanks for your advice. Brian Comment 10: I am having the same issue Fatal error : Out of memory (allocated 66322432) (tried to allocate 68 bytes) in /home/XXXXXX/public_html/lib/weblib.php on line 1202 Shared hosting at hostgator - Their reply is ¬†It appears your script is trying to utilize 66MBs of memory whereas the PHP memory_limit is 64MBs I have 8 courses and about 200 people a day accessing the site. ¬†It is only with a recently added course I am getting this problem. Before I go to VPS hosting I need to confirm that will in fact solve the issue. Comment 11: If memory is really causing the errors youre experiencing perhaps go and vote for MDL-25458 Comment 12: Done it! Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle testing script
Post description: Hi, I work for Totara, which is a distribution of moodle, and as part of our QA process we've written a number of test scripts designed to automatically check a site for various types of errors. We run these scripts on a number of installs (windows and linux servers, different databases, etc) before each release. The first script is a spider which follows all the internal links looking for PHP errors, database errors, missing language strings, 404s and moodle error boxes. It includes some whitelisting so you can exclude 'known' errors. It should also be fairly easy to extend to include other types of checks. The code is here: https://github.com/totara/Totara-test-scripts/blob/master/link_checker.php Since the script runs on any moodle site (it was designed for 1.9 but seems to work on 2.0 too), I thought I'd share it here. We've got some other scripts too but they are a bit specific to our setup at the moment - I'll try and tidy them up and add them to the repo too. Simon

Forum Post: 
Post title: Where are the legacy course files stored?
Post description: Pardon my ignorance (and I know file handling has changed with Moodle 2) but where are the legacy course files stored within the moodledata folder. Previously the course files folders would be named 2, 3, 4 etc to coincide with the course ID. I can't seem to find where these folders are held within the moodledata/filedir folder. Running a clean install of Moodle 2.0 (build 20101125) and have enabled legacy course files within the appropriate areas. Thanks Ali
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I know this has been post long time ago... Now I'm running a clean 2.0.3+ install and I have sort of the same problem.¬† Could you find the folders or the place where they are stored now?
Comment 2: Hey. First, it's likely safest to pretend they're not stored in the file system anymore.¬† This isn't true, but may be soon.¬† So, I'm assuming you like to use a script or other method to directly manipulate or read from files in 1.9.x or earlier Moodle Files areas.¬† It's probably best to just not do this. Nonetheless, technically, they are in fact stored in 2.0.x (well, at least 2.0.2). A disclaimer:¬† I'm determining this by glancing at the code and by some simple spot-checking.¬† Although I'm fairly certain, I can't guarantee I'm right.¬† Plus, this requires at least a passing understanding of Moodle code, files hashes and Linux. The files are stored in your $CFG-> dataroot dir., under the filedir dir. (at least they are in 2.0.2).¬† They are named according to an sha1 file hash.¬† See file.php in $CFG-> dirroot dir.¬† They are, within filedir, stored in 2 levels of dirs., the 1st being the first 2 chars. of the hash, the 2nd being the 3rd and 4th chars (only based on empirical evidence, not by looking at the code ... this may be incorrect if there are more or less files than our install)¬† e.g., a contrived but illustrative example using the Linux command line from in the filedir directory: 
```text
% sha1 5x/29/5x294b696bd26a371afl95e32e05625fdf7da6cq


SHA1(5x/29/5x294b696bd26a371afl95e32e05625fdf7da6cq)= 5x294b696bd26a371afa95e32e05125fdf7da6cd
```
 So, this file when uploaded was named myFile.txt and appears to have this name in Moodle, and when you do an sha1 hash on it, you'd get back 5x294b696bd26a371afa95e32e05125fdf7da6cd.¬† So, the contents of the file in filedir/5x/29/ named 5x294b696bd26a371afl95e32e05625fdf7da6cq will exactly match myFile.txt. For reading or accessing these files, you're likely okay.¬† No guarantees, and use at your discretion.¬† I'd strongly recommend against trying to update the files, as these entries are likely stored in the database , and any external changes could cause serious problems. So, likely not the answer you were looking for, but it's also likely correct. Before doing anything, I'd strongly recommend confirming my assumptions for yourself.¬† Look at the related code, experiment on a development server , and find all documentation you can at moodle.org (I could only find http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:File_API ).
Comment 3: Are legacy course files not the "course files" that are in /repository/coursefiles along with other repositories?
Comment 4: Hi. No.¬† Those are php files, not files uploaded by Moodle users.
Comment 5: So what is the course files in the repository directory then?
Comment 6: Hey. That's what I was previously trying to explain. ¬†I was very brief, though, so I'll do a better job here. Still, so focus isn't lost, a summary of all this: coursefiles is a directory containing static, .php code and it will not contain (in a sane install) the directory to which files are uploaded. ¬†I can only guess at what the programs in coursefiles do, though. Here are more details. What I do know: coursefiles is a directory coursefiles is in the repository directory repository/coursefiles is¬†in the "dirroot" area, or the location where .php files are installed. The uploaded files are located in a separate directory, known as the "dataroot" directory. ¬†(I'm technically lying, but considering these locations to be separate is in reality accurate most if not all the time. ¬†I'm fairly certain they cannot be the same, but one could have one inside the other ... it'd just be a bit weird and counter-productive, and thus is rarely or never done) So, to repeat, this is the area where Moodle programs are stored (so, the code). ¬†It's static. ¬†This does not contain files uploaded by users. To better answer your question: I don't know for sure. ¬†The following is just an educated (arguable) guess. The coursefiles directory contains files for a course files plugin. This is, I believe, the code that controls the Legacy Course Files area. Again, note it doesn't contain uploaded files; it contains programs--so, php code--that controls, if I'm right, files uploaded to the Legacy Course Files area (and the ability to upload said files). A hand-wavy explanation: The comments in repository/coursefiles/lib.php implies what I say above. repository/coursefiles/lib.php contains a $filearea variable which is given the value 'legacy' Through a, to me, convoluted set of class/child related functions and calls, I believe lib.php calls the get_area_course_legacy function in lib/filebrowser/file_info_context_course.php , which checks the value of the parameter representing the previous lip.php's $filearea, and does what seems to be Legacy Course Files area "stuff". ¬†Further, again in a tough-to-follow-way, get_area_course_legacy instantiates a file_info_area_course_legacy object which uses Martin's file.php hack for the Legacy Course Files area (file.php is in the "dirroot" directory). This is a bad way to understand a program; if I needed to know more than the fact that coursefiles does not contain uploaded files, I'd have to be way more certain. Cheers
Comment 7: Sorry.¬† I screwed up a link:¬† it should be http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:File_API No closing parenthesis.¬† My bad for avoiding to test the links in my post.

Post title: Programmatic generation of Drills and Tests from Db
Post description: Can someone please tell me if the following concept is currently available, potentially possible, or precluded by structural assumptions in Moodle? Rather than constructing individual quizzes, I think it should be possible to build various kinds of drills followed by tests, all of which are drawn programmatically from databases. Imagine, for example, a database of birds that includes fields like <common name>, <scientific name>, <audio file of call>, <image of male>, <image of female>. ¬†Imagine that the database consists of 1000 birds, and the ornithology students are expected to master all the data it contains. Drill and Test templates could be designed that give data with some fields (e.g., <call> and <image>s) and ask for (and validate against) <common name>. ¬†Another template might give <common name> and ask for (and validate against) <scientific name>. Individual drills or tests based on those templates would give limited numbers of questions filtered by certain fields. ¬†E.g., Drill 1 consisting of 50 birds whose field is listed as <Unit> = 1. ¬†Drill 2 would programmatically load items where <Unit> ‚â§ 2. ¬†Etc. A Test could be assembled by stipulating: Question 1 uses Template X and record id Y. Such a module would be applicable to a wide variety of fields and would allow much more rapid drill and test design. ¬†Faculty could input the database to Excel, save as .csv, and upload to db. Again, suggestions as to feasibility and how to get it done if it is feasible would be much appreciated. ¬†Thanks.

Post title: Blank Pages on Moodle 2
Post description: Hi I have installed and used Moodle v1.9 etc and had no problems, but have now come to install a test version of V2 on a different domain but with the same webhost (heartinternet) but getting blank pages when trying to access admin or turn editing on... in fact when I try to do a lot of things. I am getting a; Fatal error : Out of memory (allocated 32768000) (tried to allocate 16 bytes) Error in debug mode but I have changed my php5.ini file to; upload_max_filesize = 40M ; post_max_size = 40M ; max_execution_time = 360 ;
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David, Thanks for your help with testing Moodle 2.0. I'm going to move your post to the testing and QA forum where hopefully someone will have an answer...
Comment 2: Thanks Helen No one have any insight into this problem?
Comment 3: I am having exactly the same problem with 1.9.x I have a current ticket about this with Heart - hopefully, we can get it solved. Did you manage to solve the problem at all?
Comment 4: Hi, I am having the same problem, did anyone figure this out? Many thanks.. Simon.
Comment 5: Hi Simon, Please see the blank page FAQ in Installation FAQ for advice on what to check. Please post back here with feedback on what you found, such as error messages.
Comment 6: I have a client at www.totalqualityhosting.com who reported this problem.¬† It took a while but I finally figured out that the documentation is wrong/misleading as to the amount of memory required to be set in php.ini.¬† The documentation says 32 MB is enough but it seems this is not so becuase after checking just about every other thing you can think of¬†I decided to up the memory allocation to 64 MB and.... it seems to have solved the probelem.¬† This may be server specific I don't know but I would suggest you try upping the memory allocation and see if it solves the problem for you.

Post title: Web services (XML-RPC) and UTF-8
Post description: Hi all. I have been working on porting my extension ( Joomdle , Joomla-Moodle integration) to Moodle 2.0. It used the old mnet web services infrastructure , so now I moved to the new one . Everything works fine, but I have a doubt: in old system, you did not need to encode your strings (for example pulled from DB) to utf-8 before returning them in your function. That would be done by mnet (I assume). Now, in Moodle 2.0, strings are not automatically encoded to utf-8, as shown by inspecting data with wireshark, even when the xml header says is utf8. If I do a utf8_encode (text) before returning it in my web service function, it will trasfer all right. So, my question is: is this intented behaviour? Do we need to encode before returning? Or am I missing something? Thanks in advace for any insight. Antonio
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: All data in Moodle has been utf-8 since Moodle 1.6. What makes you think your data is not UTF-8?
Comment 2: Hi. Thanks for the quick response. Well, I guess that is not the problem then. I don't really know what is happening, so that is why I am asking. I will try to explain the best I can: Looking at the traffic with wireshark, I see a difference in 'format' (forgive me here, I am not that familiar with encodings/formats). I return the char '√°' in a web service, and look at the traffic: In Moodle 1.9.x, info is coded on wire as: Ã¡ In Moodle 2.0, info is: \303\241 If in Moodle 2.0, I do: utf_encode ($text) before returning, info is: Ã¡ So, it seems it is really transmitting it in utf-8, but 'another way'. As I said, I am not very familiar with encoding issues, so I don't know what this means. Thanks, Antonio
Comment 3: Hi all. I kept investigating the issue, and I think I have found the solution to my problem. Will post it here in case it can help anyone. A more correct wording for the problem description I gave could be: special chars are not converted to XML entities when trasnfering through XML-RPC. Again, forgive me if I am not using the right words. So, the problem for me was that same client code that I used for Moodle 1.9 web services, was giving me problems with special chars in Moodle 2.0. In my code for 1.9 I had: $file = file_get_contents($moodle_xmlrpc_server_url , false, $ context ); $response = xmlrpc_decode($file); This would work OK with special chars in Moodle 1.9, but not in 2.0. Changing it to this: $response = xmlrpc_decode($file, 'utf8'); seems to do the trick. Thanks, Antonio
Comment 4: In which file I can find this code?
Comment 5: Hi. That is not Moodle's code, but code from my app (joomdle)¬† to connect to Moodle. Antonio
Comment 6: Hi I have a problem with cyrillic ... when the auth column in mdl_user is "joomdle" there is problem but when I change it to "manual" there is no problem. The problem is when I update the profile (look at the pic). In the file auth.php in the most of the rows have encoding - utf8. Example: $response = xmlrpc_decode($response, 'utf8'); Do you know who can help me if you cant? Thanks.
Comment 7: Hi. If you have problems with Joomdle, please use the forums at http://www.joomdle.com Antonio

Post title: bug tracker terminology
Post description: In the moodle bug tracker it is possible to link an issue with another. I do not understand the difference between: has a non-specific relationship to: has been marked as being related by Example.- When I am editing BUG-001 and I link it as "has a non-specific relationship to: BUG-002", and then go & display BUG-002, I can see that it has been automatically linked as "This issue has been marked as being related by : BUG-001. Any ideas?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It is a logical completeness thing that end up being illogical. All the links are directional, and there are separate names for the link in each direction. For example, Duplicates / is a duplicate of. That works for all types of links except the one you give.
Comment 2: I always think what matters is that the issues are linked - whether you choose has a non-specific relationship to: or has been marked as being related by is not important at all. At least that's my excuse for not knowing which to choose!
Comment 3: There is another strange pair of issue links, that often puzzles me: will help resolve and will be resolved by . I think if issue A will help resolve issue B, that doesn't necessary mean B would be completely resolved by A. A could just help resolve it, but don't go all the way, some additional work on B may be required. So I'm perplexed, whether to set will help resolve link, if the issue will help, but not completely resolve another one.
Comment 4: Oh yes, that one irritates me a bit too.
Comment 5: Any ideas for renaming the second one? I could try somethink like Get help from , but people who know English better could probably think about better phrases...
Comment 6: The exact details of what each kind of link means is pretty unclear. To me at least. The main thing is that a link of some type is created so that the person who will ultimately resolve that issue knows about other related issues and can deal with them all at the same time.
Comment 7: Well, I at least want some clarification on ambiguous link mentioned above. Is it mean A will completely resolve B or only help with it's resolving? That's a good think to clarify IMHO ...

Post title: Moodle 2 installation script timeout
Post description: Hi, Im facing this issue in a Plesk environment when trying to perform a fresh install of Moodle 2.0 RC1. After the initial screens selecting databace connection and environment check, there goes the database preparation and the browser waits. Then after 2 minutes aprox, instead of seeing the usual db tasks as they're completed, I get Internal Server Error 500. The access.log displays the HTTP 500 error: 109.242.90.70 - - [04/Oct/2010:19:13:12 +0300] "GET /moodle/admin/index.php?agreelicense=1&confirmrelease=1&lang=en HTTP/1.1" 500 1099 " http://diadrastikon.hilabs.com/moodle/admin/index.php?lang=en&agreelicense=1 " "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.10) Gecko/20100914 Firefox /3.6.10" and the error log displays: [Mon Oct 04 19:14:43 2010] [warn] (110)Connection timed out: mod_fcgid: ap_pass_brigade failed in handle_request function After that, the database has from 50-65 tables created, not the same number every time (and yes, I've tried many). My hosting provider says this error usualy comes from the client, but I doubt that it happens in my case. Should I try to experiment with set_time_limit ( secs ) in moodle/admin/index.php where the timeout occurs? Is it something else you guys might know? THanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Please Help help help! No way I can do Moodle 2.0 RC1 installation. Script times out with a fastCGI error from mod_fcgid module. After the environment check, it rests with a server 500 error. ( [warn] (110)Connection timed out: mod_fcgid: ap_pass_brigade failed in handle_request function) After some searching, I've found that setting IPCConnectTimeout 20 IPCCommTimeout 300 might do the job (in secs) in httpd.conf Having no access to httpd.conf, I tried the .htaccess approach with no luck: "AllowOveride not allowed here" message, so I guess the use of .htaccess is not an option. PHP supportis set to run as FastCGI application and FastCGI support is checked in Plesk control. I've searched more and found this: ------------------- Running a PHP script under mod_fcgid was causing a 500 error to be returned.¬† The error logged was: mod_fcgid: read data timeout in 40 seconds (110)Connection timed out: mod_fcgid: ap_pass_brigade failed in handle_request function There is a 40 second default on the script running. To fix this for the requirement we needed to modify the vhosts.conf file for the Plesk domain and put in: <IfModule mod_fcgid.c> ProcessLifeTime 7200 IPCCommTimeout¬† 7200 IPCConnectTimeout 300 </IfModule> And rebuild the configuration file with: /usr/local/psa/admin/bin/websrvmng ‚Äìreconfigure-vhost ‚Äìvhost-name=domain ---------------- Do you have any idea what is this? I'm completely lost. I have so much work to do, going crazy with that. Even if I have to change provider, I got to know what should I ask for support. Any help will be appreciated, somebody must know something.

Comment 3: Thank you so much Helen, I was starting to believe I was talking to myself :/ Have a nice time, ag
Comment 4: I found the following link, quite enlightening I beleive http://www.moe.co.uk/2010/04/12/mod_fcgid-ap_pass_brigade-failed-and-premature-end-of-script-headers/ It is still on provider's hands...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 2.0 Parent role (mentor)
Post description: In 1.9 you can create a Parent role of a student by making a new, limited role and assigning it to the children of a parent in the user context . However - I don't see "assign roles in user..." in Moodle 2.0 (and I am not complaining because I never knew what it meant for ages) but I wondered if it has gone - and therefore - how would you make a mentor/parent role?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In Moodle 2.0, you can only assign a role in certain contexts. You choose those contexts when you create or edit the role. For example, by default, you can only assign Teachers and Students in courses, and you cannot assign any of the default roles in the user context - hence that tab does not show up. However, if you create a Parent role, and say that Parents can be assigned in the User context, then that tab will appear. The whole idea is to simplify the options as much as possible, and to help people avoid common mistakes like assigning Students in the system context. (If they really need to they can, but only by changing the role definition first.)
Comment 2: Ah I get it - I will go and experiment; thanks.
Comment 3: Thanks, it really is more simple.
Comment 4: Hi I don't get how to do this I have created a parent / mentor role and assigned this to a user. How do I then assign a student to that parent / mentor?

Forum Post: 
Post title: unicode error
Post description: I have been testing the different installs & find the following error message with Moodle 2 RC2 - today's build & yesterday's: It is required that you store all your data in Unicode format (UTF-8). New installations must be performed into databases that have their default character set as Unicode. If you are upgrading, you should perform the UTF-8 migration process (see the Admin page). There isn't a problem with RC1 - or the build from Sunday or 1.9 - I only get this with RC2. Clearly all is in unicode format already. I did however turn on & made InnooDB the default engine a few days ago. But then the other installs are not showing this message.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I had a problem with UTF-8 a few days ago.¬† I was surprised to find that many of my fields were set to Latin1.¬† It looked like an impossible task to fix it. Thankfully, I found a free tool that did it for me.¬† I backed up my database then¬†ran¬†this script¬†and it worked GREAT.¬† It fixed¬†the database¬†in just a few minutes. Take a look at http://www.phoca.cz/documents/38-tools/154-how-to-change-collation-in-database Clarence
Comment 2: Thanks Clarence but surely the problem lies in the Moodle installation. I've been installing Moodle for years & the first time I get this error was yesterday & I have also installed other versions today with no problem. I don't even get to install the database - I get the error before that stage.
Comment 3: It's entirely possible there's a bug in Moodle however a change was made a few days ago that means Moodle now reports a fatal error if it's database contains tables that are incorrectly set up. Sounds odd that you're getting it pre-install. Is it checking your defaults maybe?
Comment 4: It seems that I needed to edit /etc/my.cnf ( mysql config file) and add the following under the [my sql d] section: collation_server=utf8_unicode_ci character_set_server=utf8 character_set_client=utf8 default_collation=utf8_unicode_ci Installs of the latest 2.0 are fine now. To save a lot of time, this would be worth mentioning in the install instructions.
Comment 5: thx clarence! i fixed the problem with this script.

Post title: Problem with cohorts in categories
Post description: Hi, In a new installation (Moodle 2.0, Build: 20101125) I uploaded some testing users (Student1, Student2, etc.) When I try to make a cohort named "Students", with ID "S-1", I get a blank page. The Apache error logs say nothing, but the Moodle debugging systems shows the following error: Fatal error: Call to undefined function can_edit_in_category() in F:\www\soporte\lib\navigationlib.php on line 3501 I'm using a Win-XP machine, with Apache 2.2.11, MySQL 5.1.22-community and PHP 5.2.8 I checked the databse with phpMyAdmin and the cohort is there, but it isn't visible through Moodle (you can't add users). The cohort is also visible in the course (when you try to enrol students). If I repeat the process choosing the system level for the cohort, everything works fine. Does anybody have the same problem or do you think that something is wrong with my installation? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hey David, same problem here. Seems like they fixed it tonight. Wait for 2.0.1 http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-25397 Regards Tobias
Comment 2: Just to clarify, you don't need to wait until 2.0.1 is released to obtain the fix - you just need to download a 2.0+ package. If you do a CVS checkout (as explained in CVS for Administrators ), you will have a 2.0+ package. Alternatively, you can wait for a 2.0+ download link to be added to http://download.moodle.org/ .
Comment 3: Tobias and Helen, Thank you for your help! I'll try what Helen sugests (the use of CVS). David
Comment 4: Well, in this case you can also do the changes manually. In the file: [moodle]/lib/navigationlib.php Go to line 3501: 
```text
if (can_edit_in_category()) {
```
 And change it like this: 
```text
if (has_any_capability(array('moodle/category:manage', 'moodle/course:create'), $this->
context
)) {
```
 With this, everything works OK (thanks to Sam Hemelryk, who did the modification). Sources of interest: The mentioned bug above . Sam's GIT virtual space . Moodle's GIT site .

Post title: Performance
Post description: My site is not that big, and there are not a lot of students... Checked the size and optimized my database , it is just a little over 30meg, so not big at all. But since the upgrade to 2.0 from 1.9, the biggest thing I am finding is that the site loads really slow...¬† 30 seconds or more sometimes to load a page... Anyone else experiencing this, or have any thoughts to correct it? TYVM, Rob
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Rob, See this discussion . Joseph
Comment 2: TY TY reading it now... Did a search on it before posting, but found nothing... Thank you for posting
Comment 3: Take a look at this...¬†¬† There is something wrong here...¬†¬† PLEASE HELP ME... 133.572629 secs RAM: 22.5MB RAM peak: 22.7MB Included 351 files Contexts for which filters were loaded: 16 Filters created: 32 Pieces of content filtered: 16 Strings filtered: 0 get_string calls: 206 strings mem cache hits: 177 strings disk cache hits: 29 DB reads/writes: 150/16
Comment 4: I am seeing¬†noticeably slower performance with 2.0 than 1.9.¬† However, it is unusual for a page to take 30 seconds to load. I have been hoping this decrease in speed was due to diagnostic code in the beta version which won't appear in the production version.¬† If that is not the case, I hope the moodle developers will take some time to optimize the code.
Comment 5: Yes, performance is being looked at (e.g. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=162045 ). Think about performance a bit when designing the code. Code the desing as clearly and simply as possible, so that it works correctly. Measure the peformance in real situations, to find where the bottlenecks are. Fix the bottlenecks. Moodle 2.0 is currently starting on Step 3.¬† A lot of good design decisions were taken at step 1. which should help performance in the long term, once things have been tightened up. On the other hand, Moodle 2.0 has importnat new functionality like the navigation, and so you should expect it to be a bit slower. Moodle 2.0 beta versions does not have any test code that will be removed from the live version. The toggle between testing/development mode and production mode in Moodle is done using the admin settings, for example debugging, JavaScript and CSS caching settings, etc. (The all default to the settings for production.)
Comment 6: Hi Rob Plz use yslow tool for find where your page consume long duration for loading.... after that you will get idea for optimized your site.
Comment 7: Moodle 2.0 feels fast to me (no measurement made) on moodle.org in general, otherwise it is slow for me as well which is a cause of concern. http://www.woorank.com/en/www/moodle.org points out that gzip is enabled on moodle.org . Perhaps, you can try the following code in some key¬†moodle php files to have partial gzip support: <?php ob_start("ob_gzhandler"); ?> Any other insight regarding moodle.org speed optimisation¬†(like mod_deflate / css etc.)¬†can possibly help in this issue.

So my courses are there, my users are there, but the problem being users are not being enroled onto courses. Any help?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 2.0 Update runs without requiring login
Post description: Downloaded the lastest Moodle 2.0 update today and extracted the files to our moodle directory. I then went to the site URL to login and the update ran as soon as clicked on the link. It did not require me to login or click on the notifications menu item. ¬†I would presume this should not occur.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It has always worked like that. Checking whether a user is logged in, and verifying their password, requires access to information stored in the database . The Moodle 2.0 code can only make sense of the data in the database after it has been upgraded to the Moodle 2.0 structure. That is why the upgrade has to run before you are asked to log in. So, you need to put your site into maintenance mode before you upload the new version of the code.

Post title: How can I add plugins to the editor?
Post description: I have read several forum posts about the current configuration of the Editor Plug-ins, and I agree that the student version of the Editor should be simplified. However, I need some of the 1.9 plug-ins to facilitate course building.¬† It seems to me that there should be an editor for students and another for course builders.¬† For example, I need to be able to translate course content to different languages.¬† The language plug-in is not included in the 2.0 editor.¬† I can do the job in HTML, but it is very tedious. Can someone tell me how to add plugins to the 2.0 editor?¬† I looked at the source code and it appears that the code is there, it is not being used. Thanks, Clarence
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In the current version of core editor it is still a little tricky but basicly you can for example place your custom plugins to your moodle 2 folder lib/editor/tinymce/tiny_mce/3.3.9.2/plugins and edit init code in file¬†lib/editor/tinymce/lib.php For example if you want to show plugin dragmath only for those people who can manage¬†system files you can add some capability check like this: if (has_capability('moodle/course:managefiles', get_system_context())){ if (array_key_exists('filter/tex', $filters)) { $xdragmath = 'dragmath,'; } } else { $xdragmath = ''; } and it will show dragmath button most likely only for¬†system administrators¬†(if tex filter is enabled) It is also possible to create totally different editor configurations for students or totally different editors for students (inside lib/editor)¬†but it's takes more time and effort... I am not sure what is the best way to separate students and teachers in that moodle 2 capability checking - there might be some function for that purpose too... In the actual init code you need to add new plugins to row starting with 'plugins' => and add the button to some of the given toolbar rows like 'theme_advanced_buttons3_add' =>
Comment 2: Hello Mauno, Thanks for the information.¬† I have looked at the code and I will try to implement some additional plugins in the next few days. It will be nice when the Core developers get time to create a utility to customize the editor. Clarence

Post title: Time to move Dropbox off "sandbox"?
Post description: hi folks, When I last looked (July 2010), the Dropbox core team wasn't taking applications for new API keys for web apps... but they're certainly now doing it. Although the Tracker item ( http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-19168 ) is marked as Resolved, I've noticed that the plugin currently is hardcoded to use the Dropbox "sandbox" (i.e. lines 35 and 53 of https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/ac582c3b2547816ac1f7695bba710c48840f0f98/repository/dropbox/locallib.php and the corresponding language strings). Is there a reason for this? Is it worth submitting a patch switching 'sandbox' to 'dropbox' (I have this in a git branch)? This enables the ability to login and browse files correctly (although I'm still getting errors importing files). Cheers, Myles C
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thanks for the info, Myles. You'll notice Dongsheng has reopened MDL-19168 in order to fix the issue you describe.
Comment 2: Hi, Myles

Forum Post: 
Post title: Can't install 2.0 Prev 4+ build 20100823
Post description: Hi all, I need to update my 2.0 Prev 4+ from build 20100818 to 20100823 (latest). This is required so I can test some features which were broken on earlier releases. Build ...818 is installed OK. As soon as I repalce the moodle directory with the new build ...823 I can't get past the database settings page of the installation process. I get the following error: Warning : my sql i::close() [ mysqli.close ]: Couldn't fetch mysqli in C:\Documents and Settings\GSisson\My Documents\Moodle\ server \moodle\lib\dml\mysqli_native_moodle_database.php on line 305 What am I doing wrong? Do I need to clear out the moodledata folder? I am using a local install for testing, orginally setup using one of the windows install packages. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: After much frustration and took the plunge and installed xampp as pre instrustion here and installed the standard packages instead of the complete install packages. Proud to say I now have Prev 4+ 20100823 up and running. Back to testing, now where was I...
Comment 2: I have tried in MacOS 10.6 and have the same problem. I can't do clean install neither upgrade.
Comment 3: Hello, I had the same issue occur with me on one of my uploaded installs of Moodle 2.0 that I created to host on Godaddy. Example: ...thedidacticproject.org\server\moodle\lib\dml\mysqli_native_moodle_database.php on line 305 However, I found a solution for my problem. I had to go to MySQL database hosting control after I created the database. Access phpMyAdmin from the database area and retrieve the Server: IP via TCP/IP . I put the Server IP in the Server Name: ______. With that information plus all the other correct data the install worked as it should and I moved on to the next screen or phase of Moodle 2.0 install. Hope that this helps someone else. Jennie
Comment 4: Need to amend comment above slightly. I put the Server IP in the Server Host: 00.00.00.00 section. Then the section moved forward.
Comment 5: After creating your new config.php ; make sure you go in and check to see that the new information has been created properly in the config.php . I found that I had to go in and edit the field to reflect the correct information found in the database host . But I have now been able to move past the original problem that is stated above. Filling in the profile page at this time ... The Didactic Project Jennie

Forum Post: Post title: Cron Post description: Seems the cron.php has stopped running... In notifications I get a message that says it has not run in 24 hours, when I try to run it manually I get this error... ```text Server Time: Sun, 31 Oct 2010 06:43:52 -0500 Cleaning up stale sessions Starting activity modules Processing module function assignment_cron ... Then the rest of the page is blank... Anyone else??? ``` Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: You may want to activate debugging and see what is happening: Site Admin -> Server -> Debugging, select "developer" and click on the "Display debug messages" checkbox. Comment 2: This is what I get... ```text Server Time: Sun, 31 Oct 2010 09:34:22 -0500 Cleaning up stale sessions Starting activity modules Processing module function assignment_cron ...
Warning: require_once(/home/rmcpheec/public_html/learning.rmcphee.com/mod/assignment/type/assignmentoffline/assignment.class.php) [function.require-once]: failed to open stream: No such file or directory in /home/rmcpheec/public_html/learning.rmcphee.com/mod/assignment/lib.php on line 2518
``` Comment 3: Try again... ```text Server Time: Sun, 31 Oct 2010 09:34:22 -0500 Cleaning up stale sessions Starting activity modules Processing module function assignment_cron ...
Warning: require_once(/home/rmcpheec/public_html/learning.rmcphee.com/ mod/assignment/type/assignmentoffline/assignment.class.php) ¬†[function.require-once]: failed to open stream: No such file or directory in /home/rmcpheec/public_html /learning.rmcphee.com/mod/assignment/lib.php on line 2518
``` Comment 4: "Failed to open stream" suggests a required file is missing from your Moodle installation and that file is /home/..../mod/assignment/type/assignmentoffline/assignment.class.php. That may also indicate the file is present but for some reason (such as file permission ) cannot be opened for read. Comment 5: In the newest download of RC1, if you check that directory, it is not there. There is an offline directory, but not an assignmentoffline directory, and the file is in there. So the question comes to, why is it looking for this file in a directory that is not there? Comment 6: I deleted the MOD directory from my server, and the cron.php file and replaced them again with ones from todays RC1 and it seems to be working now... I update my site every other day with the new version, and a few days ago there was a bad one that caused a few errors, I am wondering if this was just a left over from that copy??? Comment 7: Glad you solved. I suggest you move your old moodle folder elsewhere and copy all files from the most recent download as core files may be changed according to mod changes. Just keep your config.php (and other customization you may have). Comment 8: Hi R McPhee I just checked the Moodle 2.0 RC1 tgz install pack from Download Moodle site and it does not contain that assignmentoffline folder. However, by looking at http://cvs.moodle.org/moodle/mod/assignment/type/?pathrev=HEAD I can see this directory sometimes existed in Moodle source code history. That lets me guess that you use CVS to update your 2.0 installation. If so, please make sure that you pass -P parameter to the cvs checkout command to prune empty directories. Without this parameter, CVS checkout fetches empty legacy/obsoleted directories from CVS, too. But Moodle considers every directory in that location as a plugin and expects the file there. HTH Comment 9: David, what is your opinion about Moodle, when it encounters this error, outputting a moodle debug message but continuing instead of giving an error and stopping? This issue seems to come up fairly regularly and it would be nice to be able to stop it happening once and for all. Comment 10: Andrew, I am a bit worried of a performance issue if we checked that during the production mode. You would have to regularly check if the library file exists before you require it. The require or require_once itself is not very cheap call itself, too (because of how eventual symlinks and all other machinery in the file system is evaluated) and adding extra file_exists() would make it even worse. I personally prefer the current behaviour: if the folder exists, it is expected to be full plugin. Empty folders are just a bug in the installation. Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is Moodle 2 RC1 ready for full use?
Post description: We are currently piloting Moodle using V 1.9.9. This exercise should be over by the end of this year. If found to be good for our context , for actual use from Jan 2011, can we install Moodle 2 RC1? Thanks in advance Tom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Probably yes. By then it will hopefully be Moodle 2.0 final, or at least Moodle 2.0 RC N for some larger N .
Comment 2: Hi Tom. Moodle 2.0 (the final release) should be ready for you to use by then. However, make sure that you allow some time to upgrade and for people to find their way around after you switch.¬†Quite a lot has changed (for the better) in Moodle 2.0 so unfortunately there will be some relearning to do for both teachers and students. Also, when deciding whether or not to upgrade for actual use in early 2011 you should be aware that while the 1.9 versions of Moodle are very stable 1.9 isn't going to see much in the way of new features. Moodle 2.0 is where most of the new development is happening. By moving to 2.0 you have the opportunity to help determine what form this new development takes however 2.0 hasn't been field tested to the same degree as 1.9 so there may be a few little bumps along the way.
Comment 3: Thanks a lot for yor views. Tom

Post description: In moodle 2.0 link to the section is added to breadcrumb. This produced some unexpected behavour. Steps to reproduce: 1. Go to the Moodle Features Demo Course, and in any assignment. 2. Choose "assignment" on the breadcrumb - you are now looking on the course in one-topic mode. 3. Choose "Moodle Features Demo" on the breadcrumb - you are still in one-topic mode. 4. Logout and login as the same user again - you are stuck in one-topic mode (unless you press "show all topics" icon). This is more serious bug then it may be seen because I frequently notice that many moodle users even after year of experience don't know about one/all-topic icons. These white squares don't draw much attention. It is often needed to show confused students how toggle all-topics more, and now that will be a lot more often. I guess this should be fixed.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: See MDL-23283 : Show only topic n/Show all topics" feature should be removed from 2.0.
Comment 2: Now that moodle.org has switched to moodle 2.0 RC, moodlers can experiment for themselves the problem mentioned in this thread and well described by the OP . Please vote for MDL-23283 if you agree that the Show only topic n/Show all topics feature has become obsolete, is distracting and should be removed from moodle 2.0 altogether. Joseph

I uploaded an image via FTP to repositories/FileSystem/images and used the File Picker to incert the image into a course.¬† Then I decided to¬†edited the image in Photoshop and uploaded it again via FTP to replaced the old version with the updated version using the same file name. When I tried to incert the updated image into the course, the File Picker would not let me reselect the file.¬† It said "ERROR, file already exists".¬† It would not overwrite the file already stored in the database . I had to rename the image file and using the File Picker select it and incert the updated image into the course under the new file¬†name.¬† That means that the OLD IMAGE FILE is still in the database taking up server space.¬† There is no way to delete the old file. I have reported this as a bug in the Tracker MDL-24410 Clarence

Forum Post: 
Post title: Upgrade to Moodle 2.0 from 1.95
Post description: I'm trying to upgrade a copy of our 1.95 site to Moodle 2.0, to get a handle on the new features, etc. After several hoops, I got to a screen like (sorry, I don't have the exact): Migrating course 3/5, and a bar at 60% It sat there for a while, with no indication of what to do. So I refreshed the page, and then I got the error: column "block_instances->pagetypepattern" cannot be modified. Dependency found with index "mentor_blocinst_pag2_ix (pagetypepattern)" Now all I get is "Error reading from database ". So it seems the upgrade went fubar. As I said, this is a copy, so no big loss. But is there a fix? Should I start the upgrade over? Also, it'd be nice if the main 2.0 documentation was updated. "September XX" and we're half way through September already...
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David, Sorry to hear you've run into a problem upgrading to Moodle 2.0. Unfortunately a recent bug fix caused the problem. Please see Can't Upgrade from 2.0 rev 09/10 to 09/14 for more details.
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply. I did find that after posting (silly me for not simplifying my search first). But...I'm not sure how to fix it. Through the website, I only received "Error reading from database". Even after dropping the index. I restored my database and data folder, and thought I should drop the index first. But upon restore, the index isn't there. So, it seems it's created by the upgrade procedure???
Comment 3: I see from the issue tracker this morning that the bug was supposedly resolved....except, it isn't. I restored my database and data folder, downloaded the 0915 build, and tried upgrading again. I still received the same error regarding the index. This time, I ran the "drop script" before clicking "continue" on the error message. However, I still end up at the "error reading from database" message.
Comment 4: I restored again, and dropped the index from the table "block_instance" which I understand was the old name. That gets the upgrade past that error.
Comment 5: Have you got Debugging turned up to max? and if so, did you get a useful error message when your upgrade failed. If so, please tell us what it was. Also, the fix really did only go in mid-morning UK time, so it is probably not in the 0915 build. Unless you are using CVS , you will probably have to wait until tomorrow.
Comment 6: Thanks for the reply. No, sorry. My debugging is the default (off, I assume). I only got the message about the index as above. I did successfully upgrade, dropping the index first, so I'm good for now. But I will test the upgrade again before putting it on any of our live sites, and will report back.
Comment 7: Of course, it's all relative... Now that I've had a full chance to review, most of our site is broken. We heavily use SCORM , and it appears none of the SCORM links work any longer. I was under the impression this stuff would upgrade automatically. If not, that should be better documented on the upgrade page. I understand this is still being worked on, but as soon as you guys say this is "official", somebody will drop this on their live site and be severely surprised. Also...it appears the course files are no longer browse-able via the file system. Is that correct? If so, this is going to be an administrative headache...
Comment 8: David, I'm glad to hear you've now managed to upgrade to Moodle 2.0. We try to ensure a smooth upgrade for Moodle sites using core code and rely on members of the Moodle community to test the upgrade and report any problems so they can be fixed. Please report obvious bugs in the Moodle tracker.
Comment 9: David: Also...it appears the course files are no longer browse-able via the file system. Is that correct? If so, this is going to be an administrative headache... The new 2.0 files system is being discussed in various places: in the forums: Course Files (or lack off) in Moodle 2.0 and other thoughts Course Files management in 2.0 in the tracker: MDL-23308 in the Moodle 2.0 documentation: Category:Repositories and more specifically Legacy course files on Mark Drechsler‚Äôs Blog : Dave‚Äôs Moodle 2.0 File Adventures Hope that helps, Joseph
Comment 10: Thanks very much for your help.¬† I understand there are lots of folks working on this, and I appreciate their work.¬† Overall, it looks like a great refresh of Moodle.¬† Hopefully my posts do not convey the wrong idea here. That out of the way, I'm a developer, but in VB, and¬†I'm not familiar enough with Moodle nor PHP to always know what's an obvious bug or something I just don't understand.¬† As a developer, I also¬†know that sometimes documentation gets left to the end.¬† At least, I do, lol... Anyway, the first one was a definite bug in the upgrade, but it seems to be addressed.¬† I will definitely test again at some point to confirm. The SCORM/filesystem, I'm not so sure.¬† What I think happened:¬† all our SCORM courses were set up in Moodle via the imsmanifest file (and NOT by pointing to a zip file), to make it easier for us to update.¬† Just trying 2.0, it appears that no longer works.¬† So perhaps the upgrade didn't work on our courses because of this? I will review the links Joseph sent also, to see if my questions are answered there.
Comment 11: David, I suggest you check whether your SCORM problem has been reported in the Moodle tracker and if not, do so yourself. Developers don't generally have time to browse the Using Moodle forums, whereas when you create an issue in the tracker, the component maintainer receives email notification of the bug. In general, if you're not sure whether something is a bug or not, it's a good idea to post in a forum. If nobody says "It's supposed to be like that", "that problem has just been fixed in the latest version" or similar, then please go ahead and report it in the tracker (checking first that it hasn't been reported already). if it's not a bug, the developer can always resolve the issue as 'Not a bug', but it's better to occasionally have 'Not a bug' issues than bugs which go unreported.
Comment 12: Thanks for the advice.¬† I didn't see it and opened http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-24239

Forum Post: Post title: Passwording cron Post description: Using preview 4, if cron hasn't run it will show up on the notifications area saying "cron hasn't run for 24 hours" with a link auto populated to /admin/cron.php However, if you have a password required for cron you'll hit cron.php and just get a white page with no error. Is there a way to add some logic to the auto-populated link that "knows" that cron needs a password - or to cron.php to throw an error if the password is missing/wrong? Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Daniel - The cron warning is actually a language string so that you can customize it to do what you want. The easiest thing is to change the string so that it says something like: The cron.php maintenance script has not been run for at least 24 hours. If you change the cron password you will have to update the language string. I did not attempt to use $CFG->cronremotepassword. Also, keep in mind that in 2.0 with language strings you have to write those to the disk after creating it so that it begins to be used. Let me know if you have any other questions. Peace - Anthony Comment 2: It is actually throwing an error if the password is missing or wrong but that error is only displayed if your site is configured to display errors. Generally whenever you get a blank page in Moodle there will be an error message but, unless your site is configured to them it, we don't display it for security reasons. Label:

Post title: CAS and forcelogin, cannot login as admin

CAS works without multiple authentification. The "login/index.php?authCAS=NOCAS" trick does not seem to work for me. It keeps bringing me to the CAS auth page. Do you have any ideas ? Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I enabled CAS multiple authentification which enables the authCAS=NOCAS link. I wish to get rid of the page letting the user choose between "CAS users" and "Other users" and just redirect everybody to CAS auth but letting the admin account to be accessed via the authCAS=NOCAS link.
Comment 2: In addition to modifying the code (maybe you could file a bug in the tracker), I think you can add a 'username=admin' parameter at the end of the URL . That should skip the CAS authentication process completely. Saludos.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Global Navigation Nesting?
Post description: Hi guys - I'm normally just a bystander, but I know 2.0 is coming and I'm SUPER excited for it. You guys have implemented so many changes that really bring Moodle to what I need it to do - to the point where, I think, I can eliminate my current need for a bridged Joomla-phpBB-Moodle system on my website. That being said, I was wondering about adding nesting features to the Main Menu on the front page . You can't... indent things, like you can on say, the course pages. For me, I want to have groups of items which stand out from each other, to an extent. I want to be able to group databases by type, for example. Ex: My current layout is something like... About Us (DB) FAQ (Glossary) Library (DB) Quick Find: Christian Denomination (DB) Quick Find: Entities (DB)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Actually, hmm, this should not be very hard as we are already store indenting levels here (always 0). See MDL-23178 You might also want to look into the Custom menu settings (search 2.0 admin for custommenu) which lets you create arbitrary drop-down menus.
Comment 2: The custom menu settings could definitely solve my problems - but they're only enabled in the standard theme and form factor. As a feature intended for global use in 2.0, shouldn't we be making sure that it's uniform in the templates that come along with?
Comment 3: Probably yes. I suppose it might not fit in to every design. I'll ping Patrick about it anyway.
