Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 2.0 Preview 3 Installation Woes
Post description: Hi guys, I'm having some pretty serious issues trying to install Moodle 2.0 Preview 3 into my development environment, and I was wondering if anyone could help me out. A little background on the server in question: It's an Ubuntu VM -based sandbox server, PHP 5.2.10, with Moodle 1.5 through 1.9 installed in different subdirectories, and links out to the office MySQL and PostgreSQL servers. I have a similar sandbox on Windows that links to these as well as MS SQL Server. It gives me a wide range of test environments, and now I'm trying to add Moodle 2.0 to it. As the VM is one of a multitude running on this particular remotely-accessible development machine, its webserver runs on a non-standard port. I initially installed Moodle 2.0 ages ago, so far back in fact that it was basically useless, so I ditched it and decided to install from scratch. No database , no files, nothing. This is a completely clean installation. When initially running the installer, it attempts to auto-detect its web address, and almost gets it right, except for the port number. I seem to remember 1.9.x and earlier getting the port number right, but the reason this becomes a problem is that I can't edit the web address displayed! The form box is disabled for some reason, which is hugely irritating. So I figured I would edit it myself using Firebug . With that done, I hit save, and go through the various DB setup bits. However, as soon as it writes out the config.php file, and before creating the database, I am redirected to the wrong address. Turns out the system ignores whatever value you put in the wwwroot box - it simply isn't passed through to the rest of the form, and $CFG->wwwroot is set to whatever the installer decides is correct. So I edited the config.php file on the server and added the port number to wwwroot, which has previously been all that's needed. When I do this and then try to access the site, it goes thoroughly mental. First, it displays this error:
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You have found a bug. Petr must have overlooked servers running on different ports when he implemented this. Please file a bug a http://tracker.moodle.org/ , and I am sure someone will fix this. (Or, if you want to have a go, the offending code is probably in install.php, lib/setup.php and lib/setuplib.php.)
Comment 2: Greg, thanks for your help in testing Moodle 2.0. Just moving this discussion to the testing and QA forum...
Comment 3: I added the issue to the bug tracker, but was informed by Petr that this is intentional behaviour - apparently I have to enable reverse proxy within config.php for this to work. However, I've done that, and now instead of getting the previous error message, I get " Reverse proxy enabled, server can not be accessed directly." This is a step in the right direction, but I'm obviously not setting this up correctly. Could anyone advise me as to the right combination of settings? I'm forwarding an external IP and port to an internal IP and a different port via a router - your basic redirect. At present $CFG->wwwroot is set to the external address and port, as it would be in the web browser. Is that incorrect? Thanks to all that have helped out so far.

Post title: Moodle 2.0 Backup / Restore
Post description: This is an involved question, but I have to ask it. In our current 1.9.x installations, we currently backup 1) the code [occasionally], 2) the database [my sql dump], and 3) the data contained in moodledata. The backups are stored in various places including tape. Now, it doesn't happen very often, but occasionally someone will delete¬†a course without making a course backup, or not include everything in the course backup, or something similar. I have to restore the sql database to another location, find the data for the course and restore that, and using the backed up code, access the site to recover the course. It's kind of a drawn out process, but reliable. My question is, how, using the new repository file system, do I make a backup that I can later restore. The code and the database is pretty much the same, but the moodledata area has drastically changed. One (at least I don't know how to) cannot locate the data associated with a course like you used to. I'm assuming that the data in moodledata is basically pointers to where the files are actually stored, but how do I resolve those when I'm having to do a restore? I hope the question makes sense ... Greg

We have been trying to update to moodle 2.0 and have been having lots of issues, some of which I have already posted here. My ict administrator has spend hours going through the database , which we discovered had some interesting issues such as language settings not being correct. If you want to know more about this I will have to get him to post more details as it went straight over my head. He has spent a lot of time going through the database and sorting this out and deleting as many contributed modules as he can find. Removing the contributed modules has helped and each time we get a bit further. (there is still more to do so if it helps I will keep people updated on this) We have tried it against an install from scratch that work perfectly!! Even upgrading between 1.9x versions works perfectly!! we have upgraded everything we can think of to the latest version. from our exploration and discoveries so far he believes that to get this to fully update we are going to need to try and make sure the databases match. So any non standard modules will need to be removed!!. This will be a big pain. Has anyone else found anything similar?? I really hope we are wrong as this will be a huge undertaking as we only have one person to attempt to do this.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tim -no; I don't understand the programming side of it either but I do know that * language stuff is very different in Moodle 2.0 * all non standard modules have to be rewritten to work with Moodle 2.0 so you wouldn't have been able to get them to work by default -not a suprise that one. * I think the issues updating are to do with the fact that it IS such a massive rewrite
Comment 2: Hi Tim, We may be a little pre-mature in expecting Moodle 2 to upgrade cleanly. They still have a lot of work to do on it. In any event, you have to remove the non-standard modules and blocks form your database to upgrade it to Moodle 2. You can do this by creating a copy of your database and then using Moodle 1.9x to remove (delete) the non-standard components from the copy. Then upgrade the clean copy to Moodle 2.0. This is how I removed the non-standard modules and blocks from my database. This is easy if you have cPanel on your server and you are using MySQL . But it can be done other ways with other database types. Here are the steps if you have cPanel and are using My SQL . Make a backup copy of your 1.9x database using cPanel Backup. It will be named yourdata.sql.gz Change the name of the backup file to something like "moodle2db.sql.gz" From Cpanel/Backup, RESTORE moodle2db.sql.gz This will create a new database named moodle2db In your Moodle 1.9x config.php file, change the name of your database to moodle2db. Be sure the username and password are correct for the new database. Open your Moodle 1.9x install and from Administration/modules/ activities /manage activities/, find all non-standard modules and delete them. From Administration/modules/blocks/manage blocks/ , find all non-standard blocks and delete them. This will clean out most of the non-standard module and block references from your database. Then, using phpMyAdmin , you can search the moodle2db database for any remaining references to the deleted modules and blocks. It is a little time consuming, but you can now finish the cleanup of your database. Open the latest version of Moodle 2.0 and copy your config.php file into the new install. You will also have to edit the root directory in the Moodle 2 config.php file to point to your Moodle 2.0 installation folder. Don't forget to change your 1.9x config.php file back to your 1.9x database name. This worked for me and I was able to get a clean (no errors) conversion of my data to Moodle 2.0 v. 3. I still have some issues in using my data in Moodle 2.0, but Martin and the development team are aware of them and I expect future versions will fix these problems. Hope this helps. Clarence
Comment 3: Thank you for your help!! I was not clear in some points !! the lang issue was only in our database I think!! i have a feeling it was poorly set up originally!! I will try the suggestions and see what happens Moodle 2.0 does seem so much better!! and I am looking forward to future updates!!

Forum Post: 
Post title: FTP or SFTP file upload
Post description: I have noticed that there is probably no way for a teacher, course creator or admin to upload a file via ftp as the file system is incredibly confusing. This may be a show stopper for some of my larger clients who regularly upload very large packages that exceed the php limited upload size of their site. Suggestions such as splitting their uploads into smaller packages or increasing the upload limit have been flatly refused. The one suggestion that has been met with some positive reception is that we have the ability to set a more granular role based upload limit. The interface would list the different roles and allow the administrator to set the site wide limit for the role. Thereafter course creators or teachers can set the course or activity limits for students if they feel they are too high. Another suggestion would be to have a general directory that would allow people to import a file after ftping it. The file would be deleted from this directory on a successful transfer to the correct course. Any other suggestions would be welcome.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I presume you are talking about Moodle 2.0? There is -or is supposed to be - the facility to webdav - might that help?
Comment 2: Scott, you're right, all of the courses are listed as numbers in when looking at the Moodledata via FTP/SFTP. That being said, while it can be confusing, it does work pretty well to upload files (and there are no limits).
Comment 3: Personally, on my server we have done what you said - I upped the php upload limit to 64Mb. Then I set Moodle to use the server max. Then in a course teachers set an assignment to use a lower max-upload size. It's not role based, but anyone submitting an "assignment" is going to be a student in all likelihood. In response to Joseph's post about it generally working fairly well- that has not been my experience, and the largest reason for this is that when you add files directly to the moodledata folder you have to repair permissions (If you're on linux) and you don't have access to the files API - meaning that you don't get file names sanitized, you don't get DB references, and you don't get anti-virus scanning. The name sanitizing is actually the biggest problem, and I had made a request a while back for a feature to assist in exactly what you're requesting: MDL-22066
Comment 4: Well, there's the filesystem repository: http://docs.moodle.org/en/admin/repository/filesystem You can FTP files to a folder (or mount SMB shares etc) and then access them from within Moodle when you want to deploy them somewhere.
Comment 5: I did a video showing how this works in practice here: http://moodle.drupalgardens.com/article/tue-06152010-1918/ftp-files-moodle-20-repository-api Really straight forward and very powerful.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Testing Moodle 2.0 - What feedback is desirable?
Post description: I've got a brand new install of Moodle 2.0 (Preview 2) and I am testing many aspects. I'm interested to know what the best approach is for reporting bugs/querying how the system is working. Is it best to post individual queries on this forum or should I be collating what I find and then biding my time? I could keep an eye on this forum and see what others report or I could just wait until the next Preview comes along and then see if my collated issues have been resolved. Any thoughts please from helpful Moodlers or developers?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This ought to be covered on Moodle_2.0_release_notes and on the release notes for the preview releases that are linked from there. What you should be doing is: if you are sure that something is a bug, first search in the Tracker to make sure that it has not already been reported. If it has been reported, then basically do nothing (you could watch the existing bug if you are interested. Or if you have significant information to add, then add it as a comment on the bug. If the issue has not been reported yet, please do report it. See the bit on Tracker about how to write good bug reports, including steps to reproduce, expected and actual behaviour. if you are not sure whether it is a bug, or if you think it needs discussion, start a thread here.

Post title: Adding blocks to Course Categories page not visible for student
Post description: Using 1.9 Beta 2 Not sure if this is a bug or expected behaviour, but when I go to COURSES->ADD/EDIT COURSES (as Admin), I am now at the add/edit Course Categories page. If I turn Block Editing ON, and add a block (say calendar) it appears fine, and I can put it where I want. But when you log in as a regular student, and go to the Course Categories page, it lists all the available categories, but no blocks appear. The behaviour is the same from within a category itself. If I add blocks (as Admin) within a category (on the add new course page), they appear fine as Admin, but they¬†do not appear to a regular student who has selected a category. The student only sees the courses listed within that category, but no blocks. If this is expected behaviour, then does that mean there is no way to add blocks to the course categories page or to the page that lists all the courses within a category?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Make sure the "Authenticated Users" role has permission to view blocks ... moodle/block:view should be set to ALLOW (that's the default).
Comment 2: Or is it that for admins, the category editing page is part of the admin tree, but for normal users, it isn't?
Comment 3: Martin D... I double checked this setting, and it is set to ALLOW for Authenticated Users. So Tim, do think that this is the "expected behaviour" for what I did? Thanks
Comment 4: It's an educated guess. I did not check the code.
Comment 5: There seems to be a trouble ticket ( http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-15946 ) open related to this same issue. Is there confirmation on whether the intent to add blocks to a course category page was intended for just administrators or for all users?

Comment 2: Cheers for the feedback Tim. It's a fresh 1.9.5+ install for me, but since yours is working it must be something on my end. On the linux web (server accessed remotely) i have going the error is slightly different: Fatal error : Cannot redeclare class courselib_test in (path to www folders)/moodle/course/simpletest/testcourselib.php on line 83 That's from a fresh install also. Can anyone else replicate this problem? I tried replacing the unittest and simpletestlib folders with the latest 1.9.5+ CVS folders and I still get the same error. Edit: Mind you the fresh install i did on my home computer was from the downloaded zip file from the downloads page. I'll try deleting and checking out the whole thing via CVS tonight.
Comment 3: Could it be an include path problem that is causing require_once to get confused and include the same file more than once?
Comment 4: Ah found the problem! I commented out this line of code: $this->GroupTest($test_name); And it works now! I found in the constructor of the AutoGroupClass class in /unittest/ex_simple_test.php, and it turns out the GroupTest class in /lib/simpletestlib/test_case/php is deprecated and was left blank similar to this: /** * @deprecated */ class GroupTest extends TestSuite { } I think the reason the page was complaining was PHP version related. On my server and on my local setup i was using PHP 5.3.0. I tried it on another setup (without the first line commented out) with PHP 5.2.* and it worked.
Comment 5: Yes. Must be PHP 5.3 related. Obviously it should work there. If you can be bothered, please file a bug at http://tracker.moodle.org/ saying 'Unit tests do not work with PHP 5.3'.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Best practices for QA
Post description: I am looking for instructions on setting up a staging environment where we can test and then deploy changes seemlessly to our production environment. We are not a school, so we do not have the luxury to take our site down for several months during summer while we upgrade moodle, customize code, etc. We must do it in real time, and we must do it with confidence that our changes will not break the system, lose users or data, etc. So we need to test in a staging environment that mirrors the production environment in close to real time. When we are satisfied that testing is complete, we would like to be able to "press a button" and promote the staging version (code, database , moodledata) to production. What is the current best practice?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, to clone a site, you need a copy of the code, the moodledata folder, and the database. For copying moodledata, rsync is a good tool. For copying the database, you can either take a backup (perhaps you have one anyway as part of your disaster recovery) and restore it on another machine. Or you could look into any replication mechanisms provided by your dbms. For the code, well the whole point is that you want to test some new code. I don't think you need a real-time mirror, at the Open University, the procedure is that we develope a bit, either custom development or merging in the latest Moodle release with our existing developments. Then 5 weeks before we are due to release we clone our live site onto our acceptance test server , and upgrade it to the new code. Then we may spend some time setting up some new courses to demonstrate any new features that need to be tested. Then we test and fix any bugs. Then we do the upgrade during our standard systems maintenance period, which means taking the live system down for about an hour one Tuesday morning.
Comment 2: I think I understand, thanks.
Comment 3: Tim, I will attempt to summarize your suggestions. Since I am trying to automate the process with scripts, I have numbered steps.
Comment 4: 6. run http://mysite.com/test/admin/replace.php to fix URLs Well remembered, I always forget about this step, but it is hard to test without it. I would add: 6¬Ω Do a quick check on the restored site to make sure it seems to be working before you update it. (Just visit a few pages in your browser and make sure nothing is obviously broken.) And I would split your point 7. to make it clearer. 7.1 Update the code in /var/www/test to the version you plan to deploy. (This might be a place where you use a CVS command.) 7.2 Go to http://mysite.com/test/admin/index.php to run the upgrade, watching carefully for any errors. 7.3 Configure your test courses to include examples of any new functionality you want the testers to cover. 12, 13, 14 is another place you might use a CVS command. You need 14.5, go to http://mysite.com/prod/admin/index.php to run the upgrade, watching carefully for any errors. 15 is wrong! You have just upgraded your production database which already contained all the right URLs. There is no need to change them. If you do the updates using CVS, then there are two cases to consider. One where you are directly using the moodle.org CVS server to update the files, and have any local customisations just as edits to those files. The more sophisitcated option is when you have your own source code repository (in which case look at SVN or GIT in preference to CVS) to manage your local customisations and tracking the official Moodle releases. Some of the details above will vary depending on which of those options you take, and I chose not to get into the details when typing the above. If you have not already done so, you might want to read CVS_for_Administrators .
Comment 5: 15 is wrong! Ah, I am glad you caught this. I will play with CVS in the steps you mentioned and maybe come back with more questions. But this is a great start. Thank you again for taking the time to explain.
Comment 6: If you feel like giving something beck, then you could spend some time improving Upgrading . I mostly agree with some of this comment: Talk:Upgrading#Come_on.21__Upgrading_has_to_be_simpler_and_clearer_than_this.21 .
Comment 7: I don't think QA or release management is same thing as "upgrading." QA is at much higher level. It depends on knowing what means to install, upgrade, and migrate moodle (three separate documentation articles that sometimes bleed into each other) as well as version control (more articles). The documents tend to focus on low-level technical details, not high level issues. For example, very first line of the Moodle migration document says There may be times when you need to move your Moodle site from one server to another This is completely idiotic statement. Of course you must move your Moodle site, and you must do it often (unless you are a thrill seeker who likes experimenting on the live site). You must have plan for it, and you must have scripts to automate such. No wonder people getting confused. That is just my comment as outsider, looking at moodle documentation. Best way to "improve" such would be to toss away and rewrite, working from top-level use caeses down.
Comment 8: You need 14.5, go to http://mysite.com/prod/admin/index.php to run the upgrade, watching carefully for any errors. If you copy the code from /var/www/test in /var/www/prod, are you sure that going to http://mysite.com/prod/admin/index.php would run the upgrade ? How could Moodle detect that an upgrade is necessary ? AFAIK , this is important, because you need the upgrade of the database, don't you ?
Comment 9: Here at San Francisco State University (SFSU) we use VMWare and it has worked quite well for us so far. We have VM (s) for development, testing, staging, and support sites which are all running with the exactly same hardware and software ( LAMP stack).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Logging framework in moodle for development and debugging
Post description: Hi All, I looked through documentation and don't find anything that outlines standard way of doing logging for development/debug purposes. I found out how to turn debugging on using the Admin console but I am interested to know if there is a good way to do fine grained and finely controlled debugging like the PEAR log package provides. I've been using error_log(), as was mentioned in forum posting by some, but that I feel is not sufficient to for fine grained debugging at different log levels e.g.. Any suggestions ?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moodle does not used finely grained logging levels. I guess we have three: Debug off Debug ALL - outputs all errors. Debug DEVELOPER - outputs additional messages about mistakes developers may make. Some of this controls standard PHP errors, other control the Moodle ways of raising errors like the debugging and print_error functions.
Comment 2: Thanks Tim for the feedback and clarification on how things work. I come from java and we have Log4j framework we use. I found PEAR logging framework to be closes to what I wanted. I guess, there is nothing preventing me from incorporating PEAR logging into my modules. With it I can configured debug log statements e.g. "log.debug("....")" and then turn off these loggers by simply setting a parameters somewhere in a config file (possibly php.ini or config.php ) and I wouldn't have to worry about commenting out these statements when I deploy to production. This I belive is equivalent to turnning debugging off using moodle Admin page. But an extra benefit of using PEAR logging is that I can probably define Class specific or PHP file specific or even Module specific loggers and turn on/off that logger only. K.
Comment 3: Yes, I read about Log4j and used it a bit, and it seems pretty cool. However, I don't feel any need for a highly engineered solution like that when working on Moodle. It is probably one of those things that differs between compiled and interpreted languages. It is just easier to go into the moodle code and add exactly the debugging statements you want at exactly the place you want them, rather than having to remember how to configure someone else's debug output.

Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: 
Post title: How moodle HQ handles quality assurance (QA)?
Post description: Hi all, I just noticed that the whole section of Moodle Control (QA) on docs.moodle.org is missing (see: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:Overview#Quality_control ). Just curious, does anyone know how moodle core team (or HQ) handle QA issues? Who are the main QA testers right now and what is the current work flow? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Martin only started writing that development everview page a few days ago (according to recent changes) and it is not finished yet, so you probably just need to wait and see. Moodle.com does not employ any testers as such. Like most things in an Open Source project, testing is distributed throuhout the world. Lots of Moodle users are also tester (more so than are developers). Obviously, the tracker is the main interaction point between testers and developers. There is also a Moodle QA team of volunteers that started about a year ago. They keep an eye on the tracker, and when a developer marks a bug resolved, they go and test tomake sure the fix works and mark it closed. That is the idea anyhow. In generaly, on of the reasons that Open Source software tends to be quite bug free is that it is run in lots of different ways in lots of different places, and users are incouraged to report bugs they find. So the software gets a lot of testing, even if it is all rather ad-hoc. Finally, some of the larger institutions that deploy Moodle do have professional software QA teams. For example, every time we deploy and update to the OU's Moodle install, we unleash our Technical Testing team of about six testers on it for about four weeks, and they test a wide range of functionality on all the browsers we support - and there are people in that team who have an amazing talant for breaking software. Still, better that they do it than our students. Also, as we develop new pieces of functionality between releases, they also do some initial testing when each feature is finished. Finally, we occasionally invite students in for usability and accessibility testing.
Comment 2: Hi, like Tim said, this page is new, so still not finished.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would recommend upgrading to the latest version of 1.8 - some changes have been made that hopefully help to improve some of the performance issues experienced in 1.8 (especially for the administrator). You may want to look at MDL-9617 , MDL 9726, MDL-8120 , and MDL-7416 - all of which are related to performance and I think there are some other ones too still being worked on. Peace.
Comment 2: I am running the latest version of 1.8.2+ and still get all the above errors. What do I need to do to resolve these problems?
Comment 3: The same here. What means this failure? Important? Fail: lib/simpletest/slowtestcode.php / ‚ñ∫ slow_code_test / ‚ñ∫ test_php_syntax / ‚ñ∫ Cannot test PHP syntax because PHP is not on the path. at [/var/local/premoodle/lib/simpletest/slowtestcode.php line 34] Thank you.
Comment 4: No, it is not important.
Comment 5: Unless I am mistaken, there are a lot of unit test functions there which mostly just exist as examples. I've been playing with SimpleTest and it seems useful but to work right developers have to train to actually use it every time. One of its best opportunities is to confirm that merges with the repository happen cleanly, A simple unit test can be something like this: function test_isloggedin(){ $this->assertTrue(isloggedin(), "isloggedin() should return true while user logged in"); } A slightly more complex one which I wrote recently: unction test_require_logout(){ require_once(dirname(__FILE__) . '/../../config.php'); // create temporary backups of user login data $backup['USER'] = $USER; $backup['SESSION'] = $SESSION; $session['USER'] = $_SESSION['USER']; $session['SESSION'] = $_SESSION['SESSION']; // we should not log out of shibboleth if ( $USER->auth == 'shibboleth' ){ $USER->auth = 'temp'; } // run a logout require_logout(); $this->assertFalse(isloggedin(), "require_logout() works if isloggedin() returns false here"); // restore shibboleth auth setting if ( $USER->auth == 'temp' ){ $USER->auth = 'shibboleth'; } // restore user data $USER = $backup['USER']; $SESSION = $backup['SESSION']; $_SESSION['USER'] = $session['USER']; $_SESSION['SESSION'] = $session['SESSION']; // log a login against the simulated logout add_to_log(SITEID, 'user', 'SimpleTest logout test', "view.php?id=$USER->id&course=".SITEID, $USER->id, 0, $USER->id); } They aren't perfect...definitely not, since I'm teaching myself how to use the Moodle unit testing as I go, and they test functions that upgrades won't break, but still gives an idea of how to use the unit testing.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Likely bug in Participants list (user/index.php)
Post description: Greetings...¬† I just reported¬†this bug in the tracker: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-10537 Our installation is version 1.7, so I don't know for sure that this bug affects newer versions.¬† But from studying the code, I believe it will. If someone can test this on the latest code, and reproduce the problem, that would be great.¬†¬† Eventually I'll get a test platform of 1.8¬†installed, and¬†upgrade our site to that version (we have some local customizations, so it's nontrivial.) ... but that might be¬† awhile, and I'm afraid in the meantime, this bug¬†will get lost in the tracker, buried among other 1.7.x bugs. Here's my description of the bug... --------------------------------------------------------- Bear with me.. this one is tricky to describe. But we can reproduce it easily, and I've been studying the code for two days,so I'm pretty sure it's a real bug. There is a bug in the user/index.php page that causes users to sometimes not display. It occurs when you have a number of unique participants <20, but a number of "non-hidden" role assignments greater than 20. Throughout this code, SELECT DISTINCT is used to count users... but there is one place where it is not used. In version 1.142, see line 323. That query does not use DISTINCT, so it will retrieve duplicate rows for any user who has more than one "non-hidden" role in the course. Maybe you have 23 role assignments, but only 19 unique users. The Participants page will say something like 19 total participants, but if you count the people (rows), you will see only 17. Get_record_ sql is retrieving just the first 20 records out of the 23 role assignments. Among that set of rows are 17 unique people. But the total count of unique users is <20, so you don't see paging commands. You just see one page, which says 19 users at the top, but has only 17 table rows. We noticed this because in one of our classes, we accidentally gave four Teaching Assistants a TA role and an Instructor Role. So we can easily fix the data and avoid this bug. There are other situations, however, where we need to have users with more than one non-hidden role... In several classes, a student in the class has been selected to act as a Teaching Assistant. So, that's a valid situation where the bug would apply if the count of students is just right... Best regards, -Garret

Post title: Problem login in when stressing Moodle 1.8 with JMeter
Post description: We are trying to stress our server using JMeter. When we have about 50 users in the system, nobody can login anymore, even admin or guest. We are using Manual accounts to authenticate. Looking at the source code and the database we have found a field in the table mdl_user called mnethostid that has to match with the value of mnet_localhost_id set in mdl_config table. At the beginning mnethostid of all users is set to 1, and mnet_localhost_id is set to 1 as well, but when we have almost 50 users in the system mnet_localhost_id has changed to 3 (we don't know why) and then it's impossible to login. If we manually update mdl_config setting mnet_localhost_id to 1 you can login again. We don't have enabled Moodle Network authentication, so we don't know why this value is changing. We are using Moodle 1.8. Anybody has had the same problem?

Post title: A Study on Free/Open Source Software Defect Management
Post description: Dear Moodle Contributors, I am really thankful to Free/Open Source Software development community for their overwhelming response to the survey on¬† practices and problems of defect management in Free/Open Source Software projects. If you have not participated ealier, you may spend a few minutes now too. The Online Questionnaire is available at: http://anu.puchd.ac.in/phpESP/public/survey.php?name=FOSS_Defect_Survey I hope you have found all the questions interesting and thought-provoking. Your answers will be kept anonymous.The data thus collected will only be used for research purpose. The insights gained from the study can further help us to extract publicly accessible defect data and determine impact of defect management practices on software quality. The results of study will soon be communicated to you. Thank You With regards, Anu Gupta Senior Lecturer Department of Computer Science and Applications, Panjab University, Chandigarh. Forum Post: 
Post title: Certificates
Post description: Was wondering if there was an easy way to change the certificate to use the¬†Topic or Quiz Title instead of the Course Title?¬† I would like to offer a certificate after the completion of each¬†quiz within a course that has¬†10 quizzes or topics. Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: (Note: This discussion should be in the Activity Modules forum ) Hi Ron, If you choose to print an activity grade on a certificate, such as a quiz, it will also print the name of that activity. However, you can also customize your own certificate type. The certificate type folder was created just for this type of customization. The easiest way for you to do this is to creat a new type for each topic by simply copying one of the default type folders and renaming it, e.g. topic1, topic2, topic3... Be sure to add your new names to the certificate/lang/certificate.php file like this: $string['typequiz1'] = 'Topic One Certificate'; Then in the certificate.php file for each type, at the bottom you will see where the text strings are added to the certificate under //Add text

Forum Post: 
Post title: mod_deflate and file.php
Post description: Hello all, I know it's a really busy time what with the upcoming release of 1.8, but I was hoping others might be able to help me pin down an issue we've been experiencing with Apache 's mod_deflate and Internet Explorer. The background to the "bug" is on the tracker here: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-8382 Essentially, files being served by file.php are being compressed by mod_deflate. Poor old Internet Explorer doesn't seem to understand this. When a user requests a zip file, it is compressed (because Apache assumes PHP's output is text, I think), and Internet Explorer cheerfully hands it to your unzipping application without inflating it first. The user is presented with an error message that the zip file is corrupt. Firefox , naturally, knows what to do. I'm trying to zero in on specific implementations where the problem occurs. I can recreate the error on Apache 2.0.58 and 2.0.59 running on a Windows box. This is our mod_deflate configuration: AddOutputFilterByType DEFLATE text/html text/plain text/ xml If anyone has the time to do so, I'd be extremely grateful if you could enable mod_deflate on your Apache test server and see what happens when you try to download a zip file using Internet Explorer. A number of workarounds exist, most of which don't require changes to Moodle code. I'd like to find out which is best and document it in the wiki.

Post title: Automated Testing of Quiz Attempts
Post description: Hi, I am new to Moodle development, so please let me know if this is not the right forum to ask my questions: I am trying to test some code that depends on successfully completing a quiz. Instead of going through the attempt manually and answering all the questions, I would like to automatically answer the questions by inserting an include file (which I can comment out as needed). I tried populating the $response object with the correct answer but I am not sure how to pre-set the HTML objects with the correct answers. I think the relevant code is between line 302 and line 339 of the attempt.php file, but I am not sure how to best approach it. Has anyone already done this? If not, does anyone have any suggestions? Any advice would be most appreciated. Andrew

I would, however, like to be able to turn on and off during runtime a simulation of input to Moodle modules/functions. This will be useful also with other areas of testing. Comment 3: Hi, Tim, thank you for your response. I just found the extensive developer documentation for the quiz module at: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Quiz_developer_docs http://docs.moodle.org/en/Quiz_module http://docs.moodle.org/en/Quiz_attempt It helps a lot but I am using version 1.7, and the doc doesn't explain a couple objects, such as $state. Post title: testing time-dependent events
Post description: Are there any tools (or techniques) used by testers to simulate real time? For example, do you have a way of setting "today" to be some arbitrary date? This would be valuable for testing real-time events in activities . For example, suppose it is February 2007 and a course contains a Workshop with submissions due by 15 Sept 2005. To allow submissions, set the simulated time to any date before 15 Sept 2005, make some submissions, then set the simulated time to 16 Sept 2005, advancing the Workshop to the assessment phase. It would be a lot easier (and more dependable) than adjusting the dates in the Workshop settings themselves. If such a capability exists, my second question is: Could it be made available to users?

Post title: Users can't edit posts in single discussion forums
Post description: I think this might be an old bug, back to haunt us in Moodle 1.7. I found it in the tracker at http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-5551 as resolved. I'm finding that where I've got a forum set up so a user can only start 1 discussion (type = eachuser), no-one can edit a post after it has been made. I've dug around in the code a bit, and I think this is how it works... In forum/post.php it tests forum_user_can_post_discussion at line 749. That function tests forum_user_has_posted_discussion where $forum->type=='eachuser' in forum/lib.php at line 2943, but nowhere takes into account whether the user has the right permissions to always edit, or the time the post was made. I'm not clear where else those functions might be used, so I didn't want to go tweaking them by myself. BTW I've checked the 1.7 release but not the latest stable branch, so apologies if you've fixed this one and I didn't notice. Jenny

Post title: Problems with role assignment in Moodle 1.7
Post description: I am new to Moodle, so perhaps I am making an obvious error, but I am having problems with roles assignment in Moodle 1.7 In some cases, once I assign a role to a pareticipant in a course, I cannot¬†remove or change it. In other cases, though I assign a role such as course creator or teacher to the teacher of a course, it¬†refuses to¬†appear against that course. Is this an error of mine or a flaw in the program? Any suggestions would be appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm not sure if this is the issue, Harry, but you really have to watch where you are when you make a role assignment. There's such thing as assigning a teacher moodle-wide, and assigning one to a category, or just to a course... So, if you assigned somebody teacher capability in the Admin block...Users->permissions->assign roles you're doing it at the 'site' context , whereas if you assign a teacher to a course, you are doing it at the context of that particular course. The tricky part is that teachers who have been assigned at the site level won't show up in the list of instructors in the Assign Roles screen for the course...You can prove this to yourself by looking at a teacher's profile. There you will see a list of all of their courses (no matter at what context they were assigned).
Comment 2: Thanks, Greg, but that does not seem to be the answer. Though I make sure I do not assign a teacher role in the site context, only in a specific subject context, the teacher‚Äôs name still does not show up. It also does not register in the teacher‚Äôs profile.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Moodle 1.7 Beta 2 and release timeline
Post description: I've been *so* keen every day for more than a week now to release 1.7 THAT VERY MORNING, but every day we just keep finding more and more bugs to fix. Eloy and I just bumped the version number to 1.7 Beta 2, because it feels like we have reached a sort of plateau now. I would like to have a final release by Tuesday 7th at the very latest. In the meantime, could we really have some concentrated testing and particularly patches from developers for existing bugs in 1.7 ? If you don't have access to CVS just post them to the tracker as attachments. Make sure you mark new bugs with "Affects versions" as 1.7 so it gets on the above list. The worst area currently is the AJAX course formats, which are not near production quality at the moment ( here is the AJAX bug list ). At the moment we have 1.7 set with AJAX off by default (look under Admin/Miscellaneous/Experimental) and the feature deferred, but wouldn't it be good to have it working in 1.7? The two developers who know anything about it are not available right now (original author was a Google SOC student and Vy is now on holiday), so your help would really be appreciated solving remaining issues. The other big areas are of course the Roles and the new database support. Please test thoroughly on real data (eg copies of production sites), trying different combinations and so on, to see if things work as expected. If you're game, you could even upgrade your production site already to get more realistic feedback (Moodle.org has been running 1.7 for a couple of weeks, for example). Lastly, even if you're not a developer, you can help with testing resolved bugs to confirm those things are fixed.

Comment 2: I switched themes, apparently to one that is not totally 1.7 compatible, so I have lost some of my features. I tried overwriting everything, but cannot get back to the original theme. I may end up deleting and reinstalling. Sigh.
Comment 3: As a quick hack repair, you can try replacing the contents of that theme directory with the contents from /theme/standard, that should let you recover enough to change settings etc.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Language Import Utility broken -1.7
Post description: Hi, When I trying to import another language package after install 1.7 beta using default language (en), There will be a empty page with nothing and the selected language package will not been installed. BTW : the internet connection works well when I perform the import operation. Tang
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This may be a permissions issue. The languages are downloaded into the data/lang directory. You could try loosing the permissions on this folder. I just tried installing Japanese on mine and it worked fine. Tim
Comment 2: Some servers do not accept some command (I forget which) in the procedure which installs new language packs on a Moodle site. This started with 1.6 so nothing new in 1.7dev. When this is the case, you should see this warning message: Because Moodle can not connect to download .moodle.org, we are unable to
do language pack installation automatically. Please download the
appropriate zip file(s) from the list below, copy them to your
/moodlesite/12/d141942315/htdocs/wsb3906903801/moodledata/lang/
directory and unzip them manually. But this does not seem to be your problem exactly. Sorry can't help any further, Joseph PS.- If someone could suggest a solution to the permissions problem generating the error message I printed above - other than changing web provider - I would be quite pleased.
Comment 3: Something that is new in Moodle 1.7 is the Moodle Health Centre in the admin section. This checks various parts of your sever setup, and makes recommendations for changes. If there is some server option that affects this, then we should work out exactly what it is, and try to find a way to add it to the health centre.
Comment 4: > the Moodle Health Centre in the admin section Can't find this. Is it actually called "Health Centre"? Where is is located in the Admin tree block? TIA , Joseph
Comment 5: It does not seem to be in the menu for some reason. I wonder why?
Comment 6: Thanks for the tip, Tim. Also works for Moodle 1.6 in fact. Too bad it's not available as a link anywhere in Admin pages. Joseph
Comment 7: Cheap web hosts will often turn this feature off in PHP for "security". If there were some way that we could change it in Moodle code, we would, but usually you would only see a message like this if there was really no way for PHP to access and download files from other web sites.
Comment 8: Thanks for all. The problem is not permission problem. The bug is if the network broken when language package download not completed, there will be some files remain in lang directory. This cause a empty blank page and after deleted all these files and run language import utility agian, it works fine.
Comment 9: Hi, I'm also experiencing this problem when installing 1.7 beta locally using Xampp. I select the Icelandic language and Moodle confirms installation but still it's not visible in the language choices. I've also verified the language files and they are downloaded onto the server. I also had this problem locally using 1.6 and others seems to be having it as well. See here and here . S.Fjalar

Post title: Duplication of resources in section and redundancy of data in a DB
Post description: The present mechanism of work with sections is very subject to
failures (bug 6270) as the information is duplicated under different tables. On a
field sequence it is inconvenient to do search as it is a text line,
instead of record in the table. It is necessary, even, that at moving a resource, the reference to it
left and from that section to which it is attributed in course_modules and
from that, whence it actually leaves (if it there is). Or to refuse from course_section => sequence in favour of the relational form (sequence it is possible to use as cache).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Testing 1.6 (dev)
Post description: Hi all, We have been testing Moodle 1.6 on our test server for a week. I am pleased to say that all the contrib tools that we have in our installation (book, hotpot, mail, quickmail, netpublish, returnfolder, upload and review assignment, form assignment, multiple search block, skype presence block, etc.) seem to work seamlessly with the new version. However, the switch to UTF8 did create a mess on our book pages in Finnish (I do not know why it affected Book pages in particular). I would like to hear about your experiences, so as to get a better picture of what we should be looking at. Rgrds, Paul.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Paul, When you said the UTF8 conversion created a mess on your book pages, do you mean the book module? Also, could you tell me what is corrupted after the conversion? The Moodle strings are corrupted or the data you input into Moodle are corrupted?
Comment 2: Hi Yu Zhang, I was referring to our own input (i.e. chapters) in the book module. It affected mainly the Finnish letters √§ and √∂ and I assume it will also cause problems with Swedish √•. We know it is still early, so we are not too worried about it (yet), but I thought it was worth mentioning. Here and there in other resources and activities there are incidental errors (probably caused by characters imported from MS Word). Rgrds, Paul. P.S. I had completely overlooked this forum, or I would have posted my message here.
Comment 3: Hi Paul, Thanks for explaining the problem. Because the book module is a contrib module, there is no code in the book module to do the conversion (yet). So Finnish letters would get corrutped after the conversion (for now).¬† Are Finnish letters converted properly in core moodle modules? Cheers, Yu
Comment 4: Hi! Book module is not ready for 1.6 yet. I have some patches for backups and restore from Penny here. I need to review UTF8 upgrade too. The problem is I do not know where to commit it, because it will not be compatible with 1.5.x - there are no cvs branches in contrib yet AFAIK . Anyway I need it for one project this week, so expect some solution soon... skodak
Comment 5: Hi all, I am flabberghasted! We had tested 1.6 dev, 1.6 beta (everything worked except the unicode conversion) and finally 1.6.1. (everything works except the Mail and Userdir/Returnfolder modules (contrib.)). So I was quite confident when upgrading our production server. Who describes my horror when not only the problem with the language conversion returned (in certain places especially in labels and blocks), but not only that, the following standard Moodle modules do not work anymore: Choice, HotPot, LAMS, Questionnaire, Quiz, Survey, Workshop and the Directory resource! The only difference between the server installations¬†is that the production server was upgraded to Mysql 5.0.22, while the test server has My sql 5.0.21.¬†Both servers run Apache 2, PHP 5.1.4 and Moodle 1.6.1. (2006050510). Does anyone have any suggestions as to the root of this problem? I am trying to see if I made any error during the upgrade (I did not receive any error messages, only "Success"), but if I do not find a solution quickly we will have to revert to Moodle 1.5.4. Rgrds, Paul.

Post title: Moodle version 1.7 versus 2.0?
Post description: Assume that I were to install, test, and develop a site using version 1.7 of Moodle, so that by the time 1.7 is in production (August of this year), the site is fully developed and ready to go. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi William, A few thoughts: Since Moodle 1.6 is not yet out, I would suggest to start with a Moodle 1.6 beta. For testing purposes, it is stable enough. Forum Post: 
Post title: Some Test Results with UTF-8 in 1.6
Post description: I have been running some tests on Eloy's test installation of 1.6 for UTF-8. I am testing its capabilities of handling Unicode extended Latin characters, as that is what I am interested in at the moment. I also have run some Arabic tests. Here are my results (all run in Windows XP): 1-I have encountered no problems with using the HTML editor with Latin extended in Firefox , whether I specify the font or not to be used, Firefox is smart enough to find the characters in fonts I have installed on my system. IE 6 is a big problem though. Unless the font is specified, it will not find the characters. And if you specify a list of fonts, it will only draw characters from the first font on the list that it finds on your system, even if that font does not contain all the characters it needs. It will not go down the list looking for other fonts that have those characters, and instead will just insert little boxes. It can recognize what you are typing, and save it in the database , but it will not display it. Consequently, anything not entered with the html editor, such as forum subject titles, search entries, etc., will not display the proper characters unless a font containing ALL of the required characters is found on your machine and is the first font IE finds on your computer from the list of fonts specified in CSS . 2-I haven't run as extensive tests with Arabic, but here are my results. Strangely enough, the first problem I noticed was with Firefox, not IE. I typed Allahu Akbar ÿßŸÑŸÑŸá ÿßŸÉÿ®ÿ±. Normally, if you type the word Allah, it automatically add voweling marks. In the html editor, these voweling marks appear, but when it renders it on the page, they disappear in Firefox, but appear in IE. Not a serious problem and may be related to the fact that different fonts seem to be standard on Firefox and IE for the test site, but just something I noticed. When I switched to Arabic as my default language on the site, more serious problems appeared (the following are only test results from Firefox, I didn't check these issues with IE6). A more serious issue is that blocks are switched to the opposite side of the page, and consequently, the arrows for moving the blocks to the other side of the page point in the wrong directions. For example, the block on the right has an arrow pointing right with the tool tip text saying it will move to the right, which would be off the screen. The names of the font sizes in the html editor are inversed, instead of 1 (8 pt) it reads (pt 8) 1. Typing English with punctuation anywhere but in the HTML editor puts the punctuation in the wrong place, so creating a quiz called "Why is it a problem?" displays as "?Why is it a problem."
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It might be worthwile seperating out what are new problems in 1.6 and which are longstanding issues. For example, the left and right columns switching thing makes some sense (as presumably the 'most important' column should be on the left if you read left-to-right and vice-versa) but it has confused me in the past that the CSS for the left-column applies to the right column in right-to-left languages. This looks really odd unless your design is mostly symmetrical. I hadn't noticed the reversed arrows but it is probably the same problem underneath. Is anyone actually using Moodle in Arabic today? Are they working around these problems somehow? The problems you describe in part 1, are also longstanding bugs I've had to deal with before, but they're bugs in Internet Explorer, not Moodle. I think the best thing to do would be to hope that IE7 supports Unicode better though there's probably steps you can take to minimize problems. I'm sure there are pages on the web that list common Windows fonts with coverage of different Unicode areas. That also might mean disabling the ability for people to choose fonts in the HTML editor or else they could choose things that they can see but others can't. (Though this is already a problem to some degree today, and I've never thought that letting people change fonts makes much sense in Moodle). I think for a long time to come recommending users download either Firefox or a particular font is going to be necessary to do various language releated tasks on the web (with or without Moodle).
Comment 2: Unfortunately, the problem I have encountered is that there is no single font that comes standard on all computers that contains every one of the characters I need. That wouldn't be a problem if it were just Firefox because it will pick and choose characters from different fonts as necessary. But¬† IE doesn't. I'm just going to have people download a special font and/or use Firefox.
Comment 3: I just wanted to report I am encountering the same problem with the short answer quiz in IE that I mentioned in my point number 1 above. In Firefox, however, it works OK, which it didn't in 1.5 if I recall correctly. The characters are not rendering properly if they are not from the first font specified on the site. I suspect that I can work around this specific problem on my site because I do not need short answers in anything but one font which I can specify in the module itself, but I can't test this hack at the moment. I successfully implemented the hack in 1.5 though. I am beginning to wonder whether there needs to be a way to specify fonts at a level below that of site, even at a level of course or even specific modules in a course when the html editor is not used, to avoid these problems. There is no single font that contains all the characters needed for all possible languages. If you had a large university running Moodle, and they taught a lot of languages, their teachers would absolutely need to be able to use different fonts to render those languages.
Comment 4: I just tried another test using Arabic this time, short answer quiz. It looks pretty good, except for an untranslated string, which I have notified the Arabic language pack maintainer about. However, there are a couple general problems I noticed this time. The first is that the numbers do not display "Arabic" (in proper English, "Hindi") numbers. I'm not sure if this is even possible on the Web, as a lot of Arabic sites don't use Hindi numbers, and it isn't absolutely a problem because most Arabs these days know and use both number sets and the "Hindi" numbers are left to right so direction is not an issue. However, I wonder if it is a problem with the number sets in other languages, like many of the Indian languages that have entirely different sets? The second problem involves the breadcrumbs. They remain on the left side of the page, except the crumbs are arranged from RTL rather than LTR. Also, the arrows in the breadcrumbs are a bit strange. They all point to the left, which is how one would expect it, as it is opposite of the normal direction, EXCEPT the first arrow, which points right. What's more, the two items which are separated by this reverse arrow, the site name and the course name, are switched. So it looks something like this (I've put it all in English but the order and direction are the same):
Comment 5: Here's something else that has come up, which may or may not be relevant. I am running 1.5 for my site. I decided to convert it, via the language pack, to UTF-8. When I did this, I noticed that certain characters already on my site suddenly became black diamonds with white question marks inside them. The characters I noticed this happen with were the German a with umlaut ( √§) and the curly apostrophe (in some text I had originally composed in MS Word and then pasted). I don't know if this is of any significance for converting sites to 1.6 but I thought I would mention it.

Post title: Survey Module Test Code
Post description: I made some minor changes in the usability of the survey multi-choice agree/disagree question types. I found the default row of buttons to be annoying. Someone might think it means "strongly strongly agree". I also thought the scale disagree-agree (left to right) to be the wrong order. I think it should be agree to disagree (left to right).¬† I think the careless respondant to the survey is most likey to click on the the buttons on the left which would be disagree. I think I'd rather facilitate agreement as opposed to disagreement. So I reversed the order of the scale (including the radio button values) and rewrote the javascript validation. I'd appreciate any feedback. If these changes found there way into the next release I wouldn't mind at all.¬† The code is attached.

Post title: Sharing Mambo's Login with Moodle
Post description: I am trying to build a site where Mambo and Moodle co-exist.¬† I don't want Moodle to show up as a part of Mambo but I would like them to share a single login.¬† My idea is to make a link on my Mambo page to my Moodle site that users could click once they are logged in.¬† The link would probably have to pass the Moodle session information and keep the user "logged in" once they pass on to the new site.¬† Any thoughts on how I could get this to work? Thanks, Jake
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Dear Jake Schutz I don't think that it has been done yet. People have integrated moodle and mambo in the past, but I don't think that anyone has combined the authentication but you should ask the people on this thread. http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=17805 Timothy
Comment 2: There is a component on this site that does just that. You will need to dl, install and configure. I recommend doing this in a test environment first. Benefits of course are a single login but I suspect that you trade off other authentication options. Moodle is presented in the Manbo wrapper so you need to ensure your manbo site is built to suit or your Moodle will not fully appear on the screen - it will not be as usable lets say. I expect that you do not need to run Moodle inside Mambo either although I never checked that out. The original project has been handed over to a new dev team and I haven't seen any progress although I haven't checked in a while either.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Testing the new timezones on moodle.org
Post description: Moodle 1.5 has a lot of new code relating to the handling of timezones and DST (thanks Jon and Martin L for their work on this!) It's complex stuff, and I'd like to see a big test of this before we put out Moodle 1.5 Beta 1. If you are reading this, can you please edit your profile right now and set the timezone to the closest region/city for you (don't use the GMT* entries). Then keep an eye on the times around Moodle (the last access date in your profile is a good one but also try some calendar entries in the far future or past). If you notice anything wierd, please post here! Make sure you include: the timezone entry you are using, what you should be seeing and what you are seeing.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Just updated my Timezone, the date is right but the time is not, the time is advance for an hour...
Comment 2: Hi Genner, The data that Moodle (and many other open source projects as well) bases the timezone calculation on seems to have been out of date in your case. The latest information we have is from 1978 and it notes the use of Daylight Savings time, while this page says that at least in 2005 Manila does not use DST. Assuming this is all there is to it, we updated http://download.moodle.org/timezones/ to not have Manila use DST starting from 2005. You should now see the correct time. If you have a local installation of Moodle 1.5, you can use the automatic timezone update function to bring it up to date.
Comment 3: Th time eis ok for my timezone Europe/Rome, but the last access date is shown in French, while my preferred language is English.
Comment 4: This was the locale switching spontaneously to fr_FR ... I've seen this before once or twice - I don't know why it happens yet.
Comment 5: Updated the timezone in my profile to Europe/UK/London. It's currently 3.30 pm in England, but I'm getting 3.30am. Also, the language seems to be Spanish even though it's set for English in my profile. Last access: s√°bado, 23 abril 2005, 03:30 ¬† (now)
Comment 6: This was just a locale problem ... fixed.

Post title: re: Bug #2991 - Setting font size to small makes world TOO small on IE6
Post description: The thread below addresses the IE font size problem. http://groups-beta.google.com/group/comp.infosystems.www.authoring.stylesheets/browse_thread/thread/c85bbaf76f0512d8/45431abe0e60237c?q=IE+css+text+size+smallest+fonts+small+text+problem&rnum=5&hl=en#45431abe0e60237c Jan 22 2004, 3:07 am¬†¬†¬†¬† show options Newsgroups: comp.infosystems. www.authoring.stylesheets From:¬† - Find messages by this author Date: Thu, 22 Jan 2004 11:09:00 +0000 Subject: Re: handling multi browser font sizes Reply to Author | Forward | Print | Individual Message | Show original | Report Abuse wrote: >Noozer / 2004-01-22 01:56: >> Why not just omit the 100% altogether? >The page author should set body { font-size: 100% } if he's going to >set font-size of any element (say h1, h2, h3, span.footnote etc >etc). This is because MSIE has a bug that causes View:Text Size >control to freak out if any font size is defined with percentage >unit without specifying font size of body element. Not true. The bug in IE is when font-size is set in ems then the size difference is vastly inflated when the user has anything other than Medium set. So the solution is to either: 1. Set 100% on the body and then use ems 2. Use percentages throughout in which case you don't need an explicit size set on the body. Compare http://steve.pugh.net/test/tes¬≠t67a.html and http://steve.pugh.net/test/tes¬≠t67b.html to see the bug in action. So it might be the¬† "font-size:0.95em;"¬† setting. body, td, th, li { font-family:"Trebuchet MS", Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size:0.95em; } - Eric ps: do I have to sign up to add to bugs or is it my 'Using Moodle' login info?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Hidden activities and resources are really hidden
Post description: In order to ensure that when a teacher hides a resource or an activity that students really can't get at it, even if they know the direct links to its pages, I have given an optional third argument $cm to the functions require_login() and require_course_login(). Pages showing information about a particular course module should pass the course module object in this third argument. The login functions will then test if either the course module is visible or the user is a teacher. If neither is the case then the user is redirected to the course homepage after being shown a message "Sorry, this activity is currently hidden". This was discussed in Bug #2450 I therefore changed most module pages and may well have made a typo somewhere, so please let me know if something stops working. (While I was at it I also turned the autologinguests off for most module pages, except on the index.php pages and the view.php pages for those modules that allow guests).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: While I was at it I also turned the autologinguests off for most module
pages, except on the index.php pages and the view.php pages for those
modules that allow guests Hi Gustav, is this a setting in the module that we can set yes or no, or does this mean that if we want guests to have access to module pages they used to have access to, we'll have to modify the code?
Comment 2: autologinguests does not affect whether guests can have access or not. It only affects whether they are logged in as guests automatically. If this option is set to yes in Administration -> Variables then non-logged in users trying to access a course or a resource or an activity that allows guests will automatically be logged in as guests. However if a non-logged in user tries to access an activity that does not allow guests then there would be no point in logging them in as guests, so I have disabled this autologin for those activities .

Forum Post: 
Post title: Front page activities
Post description: There is now a new configuration variable $CFG->allusersaresitestudents which defaults to true. As it says on the configuration page: "For activities on the front page of the site, should ALL users be considered as students? If you answer "Yes", then any confirmed user account will be allowed to participate as a student in those activities. If you answer "No", then only users who are already a participant in at least one course will be able to take part in those front page activities." Can you please test that this really works the way it should? The details are: When $CFG->allusersaresitestudents is true then all users with confirmed undeleted accounts who are not admins or explicitly enrolled as site teachers should be viewed as site students. When $CFG->allusersaresitestudents is false then all users who are students or teachers in any of the real courses but are not teachers on the site course should be viewed as site students. Not all modules follow these rules yet: Assignment, Attendance, Dialogue, Exercise, Journal and Workshop access the user_students tables directly to determine who is¬†a student. They will are using the following, independent of the value of $CFG->allusersaresitestudents: All users who are students in at least one real course are viewed as site students. The standard modules that I believe are following the proper rules are: chat, choice, forum, glossary, lesson , quiz, scorm , survey, wiki. If you have $CFG->allusersaresitestudents set to true then be careful. Site users have no way of deleting their user accounts. So if for example you use force subscription to a forum then that amounts to having people on a mailing list from which they can't remove themselves.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Would it be possible in the future to make a way for users to delete their accounts?

Forum Post: 
Post title: New Chat daemon is running on moodle.org
Post description: The new chat daemon is running on moodle.org for you to try out. You should find it pretty fast - Jon has done some great work on it so far. Finally, the chat is currently running on port 1024 (the admin chooses this). Some of you may not be able to use chat at all because of a firewall blockage. Don't worry about this, I don't plan to use the daemon in the long term on moodle.org. In a large installation like a University they could run this daemon on a small separate server for the purpose and use port 80 for maximum compatibility with everyone's firewalls. What I'd really like is for programmers to run it locally (it's in CVS on the trunk) and to see if they can help us identify some of the remaining small problems that it has. The user list is currently using the old method, so ignore that for now. The new method, which uses the daemon, is still having a few issues but should be enabled in CVS soon. Occasionally, on some browsers, you will see "Document has no data" dialogs popping up ... Sometimes, typing a message will be sent out two or three times to everyone.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Resource linking
Post description: You may not have noticed the cool little thing Eloy added recently to the Resource module - a filter for auto-linking resource names. So, for example, you can oh-so-casually mention something like the Moodle API documentation or some nice little projects and hey presto!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Better than that - he's just upgraded it to the Activity names filter which works on all activity names in a course, so you can now talk about the forum module, or the open chat lounge and ...
Comment 2: That is very cool! Thanks E and M.
Comment 3: That rocks! I mean, ahem, that is a very nice feature.¬† Thanks! --Greg
Comment 4: It is absolutely cool! One thing, though, it also links if you mention the resource in a quiz! I found this on my final test for the semester. Fortunately the students didn't recognize it for what it was--automatic "cheating". It is easy to stop it (<unlink>resource name</unlink>), though (Art showed me this). It is only a problem for me with quizzes if I am counting them for a grade, and the linking is such a nice feature that I am VERY willing to deal with this! People should probably be warned, though. --Mary
Comment 5: I can't get the auto-linking feature to work on our moodle installation - is anyone else experiencing problems with this? Morag

Forum Post: 
Post title: Logging in visitors as guests automatically
Post description: Since day before yesterday there is an option autologinguests on the site variables page that¬†allows you to configure your site so that any visitor that is not logged in is logged in automatically as guest user when entering any course that allows guest access. See http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=9161 . This makes Moodle behave more like a CMS and this may be appropriate on certain sites. It is possible to disable this autologin on individual pages by giving a second argument equal to false to the require_login() function. So if you are using this autologin feature and find that it is inconvenient on particular pages, let me know and I will add the false argument to the require_login on that page. Unfortunately I will be away on holiday for two weeks without email contact. But when I come back ...

Post title: New HTML editor
Post description: The new HTML editor (HTMLarea) is now in CVS , as of version 2003102900. I integrated Janne's great work so that using the new editor is optional. Unless you activate it everything will continue as before. To activate the new editor (as I have done on this site already) just include this line in your config.php. $CFG->useneweditor = true; Eventually (when the new editor is more polished) it will be the default editor. Comments, bug reports and other work can all go in the new HTML editor forum .

Post title: Modular quiz reports
Post description: There is now a modular system for quiz reports in mod/quiz/report/xxxxxx/ in CVS . Modules can be written that produce reports on the current quiz and dropped into that directory. Post title: A module suggestion...
Post description: I was setting up Moodle for a friend of mine who will be using it while teaching high school theatre next Fall. As I was helping her add in some sample Assignments, she asked me if there was a way to place Holidays and other "events" in her course (which is in weekly format). We settled on creating Assignments that were simply text with the Holiday name and "No School" as the description. My suggestion was, how difficult would it be to create a module for "Events" that could be used for class holidays, special events, announcements, or specific news items that need to fall chronologically in a class. Maybe there is an existing way that I am just missing...any thoughts? Oh, and by the way, I am BLOWN AWAY by Moodle. I am turning all my teacher friends onto it! Keep up the great work everyone! -Jeff
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: See that queue of people over there going into that tent marked "calendar"? That's probably where you want to be. Personally I think it's best to keep this separate from the course activities , hence I'm planning to put it into MyMoodle, a user-customised page that combines information from all enrolled courses on one page. But others like their calendars different: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=1297 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=268

Post title: "Forgotten password" routine now uses confirmation
Post description: I just fixed another little thing that had been bothering me for a long time - anyone could reset someone else's password from the login screen if they now the other person's email address. The new scheme now sends a confirmation email first, containing a coded link. Clicking on the link then causes the password to be changed and mailed out as before. This should prevent a possibility of annoyance by troublemakers.
Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Small graphics can now be a part of themes
Post description: New stuff in CVS today means that themes can now contain substitute graphics for all the little icons , buttons etc. See "cordoroyblue" for an example. Unlike language packs, this feature is all-or-nothing - it would be just too time-consuming to check each time that image files exist. At the same time I made some improvements to the course main page (adding image sizes for the teacher controls etc) so it renders cleaner and more snappy now.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Improved performance on Recent Activity
Post description: I only recently noticed that users who had been away for a few weeks who were trying to get back in to this course (Using Moodle) were having the course page become very slow and sometimes never finish loading! The problem was too much data to process when creating the Recent Activity display (lots of things happening in this course!) which overwhelmed the way I was doing it (it wasn't very scalable). I've just implemented a new method which appears to give roughly the same speed for small courses, but also gives decent performance on large courses too. Yay!

Forum Post: 
Post title: "Program" resource type example.
Post description: Does anyone have any example code of an external program that can be called using the new program resource type?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well.... this is something that has occupied a great deal of my small brain... I've been using Brainstorm , a software package developed by Mark Kimes (alias Hector). It might be overkill for a lot of people because it carries the username and password from Moodle into Brainstorm so that students can become part of a collaborative library. Brainstorm is essentially a wiki (a place where guests and members can write and edit documents), but it has all kinds of comforts like administrative permissions for various users (i.e. should we let them create pages in the library, or simply comment upon existing ones, or should they be able to edit the pages and delete them?). I have not fully implemented my intended use of Brainstorm, right now I link out of classes into Brainstorm so that students can see shared resources. But soon I hope to link out to documents and have students annotate them with comments. Or I might have each student create a kind of blogging page in Brainstorm where they keep reading journals. The element I love about Brainstorm is the hyperlinking. Everytime you create a page in Brainstorm (a node), the title becomes hyperlinked to any other mention of it within Brainstorm. For me, this is a great way for a class to capture good ideas and to reference what has been said before. Someday I hope to have all kinds of nifty reference pages that capture how to write sentences, how to write paragraphs, how to write essays, examples of each, etc., so that students can visit and revisit the pages. Also, when these are complete, I'll just hyperlink from Moodle into Brainstorm in my journal comments or my quiz comments, etc.. when I'm trying to reinforce an idea. Feel free to visit my brainstorm or my moodle to see them in action. Sorry they are incomplete. I have too many papers to grade to get everything working properly. In my moodle, visit the 11th grade class as a guest, if you want. Feel free to become users in my brainstorm page. If you give me an email (threemurdocks@mac.com), I'll crank up the permissions so that you can have control over the environment. cheers (as our friend Martin says),
Comment 2: Yes love that Brainstorm idea.... and love your use of colour on your moodle site... Jai
